revision.text:
The '''2007 Koidu-Sefadu protest''' was a protest by 400 [[Sierra Leone]]ans in the town of [[Koidu-Sefadu]] in [[Eastern Province, Sierra Leone|Eastern Province]]. The protest was aimed at the local diamond [[Mining|mine]] which the residents claimed to have harmed both them and the local environment. The result of the protest was a clampdown by Sierra Leonean police and the death of 2 protesters.
==Background== Sierra Leoneans had flocked to the country's largest mine after the election of [[Ernest Bai Koroma]] in September 2007. On 12 December, the government removed the miners after it was agreed that the miners could keep any diamonds uncovered during their work.
==14 December== On 14 December, local police were ordered into the mine area to protect the [[Koidu Holdings]] company which runs the mine. Protesters had gathered at the gate, seeking housing and increased compensation for their sufferings. The police used live ammunition and tear gas to disperse the protesters, killing two and injuring eight others.
==Official reaction== On the issue of resettlement of displaced villagers, [[Ministry of Mineral Resources (Sierra Leone)|Minister of Mineral Resources]] [[Alhaji]] [[Abubakarr Jalloh (politician)|Abubakarr Jalloh]] said the "company is relatively slow in building the resettlement". Minister Jalloh also sought for the miners to leave the area. President Koroma temporarily halted diamond mining across the country as a result of the incident.
==See also== * [[2007 in Sierra Leone]]
==Sources== * [https://archive.is/20070621081243/http://africa.reuters.com/top/news/usnBAN451149.html S. Leone halts mining after 2 die in diamond riots] [[Reuters]], 14 December 2007
{{DEFAULTSORT:Koidu protest, 2007}} [[Category:2007 in Sierra Leone]] [[Category:Protests in Sierra Leone|Koidu-Sefadu]] [[Category:2007 protests|Koidu-Sefadu]]
{{SierraLeone-hist-stub}}

The station became well known for regularly broadcasting in the [[Balinese language]]. Some examples include the broadcast of Balinese songs and ceremonies. News is also broadcast, in [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]]. == Banned == From May 8 to May 11, 2013 Seputar Bali news program has been banned to airing by Indonesian Broadcasting Commission Bali Branch because its biased coverage of the gubernatorial election and the candidates (no cover-both-sides).{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/bali-daily/2013-05-10/bali-tv-told-stop-news-program.html |title=Bali TV told to stop news program |date=May 10, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615090755/http://www.thejakartapost.com/bali-daily/2013-05-10/bali-tv-told-stop-news-program.html |archivedate=2013-06-15 |df= }} == See also == * [[List of Indonesian language television channels]] * [[Media of Indonesia]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.balitv.tv/ Official Site] {{id icon}} [[Category:Television stations in Indonesia]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2002]] [[Category:Media in Bali]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Indonesia]] {{TV Providers in Indonesia}} {{Indonesia-stub}} {{Indonesia-tv-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''United Nations Programme of Action on the Sustainable Development of Small Island Developing States''', popularly referred to as the '''Barbados Program of Action''' ('''BPOA'''), is a policy document that both: comprehensively addresses the economic, environmental, and social developmental vulnerabilities facing islands; and outlines a strategy that seeks to mitigate those vulnerabilities. It remains the only internationally approved programme specific to [[Small Island Developing States]] (SIDS) which has been collectively and unanimously endorsed by SIDS.
== Development of the BPOA == The full text of the BPOA was produced in [[Bridgetown, Barbados]] in 1994 at the first Global Conference on the Sustainable Development of Small Island States, a conference mandated by United Nations [[United Nations General Assembly|General Assembly]] [[Resolution (law)|Resolution]] 47/189. The need for an islands specific conference was highlighted some two years prior at the 1992 United Nations Conference on Environment and Development ([[Earth Summit]]), held in [[Rio de Janeiro]] where 179 governments voted to adopt [[Agenda 21]]. Chapter 17, section G of [[Agenda 21]] acknowledges that "small island developing states are a special case both for environment and development ... [and] are considered extremely vulnerable to global warming and sealevel rise."
== BPOA+5 == In 1999, the [[United Nations General Assembly|General Assembly]] of the UN held a special session to appraise five years of progress on the implementation of the BPOA (BPOA +5). The Assembly recognized progress as 'uneven' and identified key trends including increasing [[globalization]], widening inequalities in income and a continued deterioration of the global environment. A new General Assembly [[Resolution (law)|Resolution]] (S-22/2) promised further action.
== BPOA+10 == The Johannesburg Plan of Implementation, agreed to at the [[World Summit on Sustainable Development]] ([[Earth Summit 2002]]) affirmed UN commitment to 'full implementation' of Agenda 21, alongside achievement of the [[Millennium Development Goals]], the BPOA, and other international agreements. To this end, it recommended the convening of an International Meeting to Review the Implementation of the Program of Action for the Sustainable Development of Small Island Developing States. Upon receipt of the recommendation, the [[United Nations General Assembly|General Assembly]] of the UN passed [[Resolution (law)|Resolutions]] 57/262 and 58/213, which mandated an International Meeting to Review the Implementation of the Programme of Action for the Sustainable Development of Small Island Developing States to take place. The meeting was held in [[Port Louis, Mauritius]] between January 10-14, 2005. The final report emerging from this meeting significantly revised the original BPOA, and verified what previous reviews were alluding to, that the implementation of the BPOA had been largely unsuccessful. What emerged from it was a reorganising of the Programs "priority areas" and an entrenched commitment to the notion that economic growth would ultimately contribute to sustainable development.
==See also== * [http://www.geol.utas.edu.au/isisa/ International Small Islands Studies Association] * [http://www.islandstudies.ca/journal [[Open access (publishing)|Open access]] scholarly journal of Island Studies] == External links == * [https://www.un.org/esa/sustdev/agenda21text.htm Agenda 21 text]. * [http://www.sidsnet.org/docshare/other/BPOA.pdf The Barbados Programme of Action], Final Report for the Global Conference on the Sustainable Development of Small Island Developing States '''(BPOA)'''. * [http://www.sidsnet.org/docshare/other/20050622163242_English.pdf], the final Report of the International Meeting to Review the Implementation of the Programme of Action for the Sustainable Development of Small Island Developing States '''(BPOA +10)'''. * [http://www.sidsnet.org/], the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs sponsored website providing a global network for small island developing States. * [http://www.sidsnet.org/aosis/index.html], official website for the [[Alliance of Small Island States]]. * [http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID=12117&URL_DO=DO_PRINTPAGE&URL_SECTION=201.html], a summary of the path "From Barbados to Mauritius" provided by UNESCO. * [http://www.islandvulnerability.org/m/ahmedm.pdf], An Examination of the Development Path Taken by Small Island Developing States.
[[Category:International sustainable development]] [[Category:United Nations documents]] [[Category:1994 in international relations]] [[Category:Barbados and the United Nations]]

[[Holy Roman Empire|German and Austrian]] mercenaries | combatant3 = | commander1 = {{flagicon|Wallachia|1632}} [[Matei Basarab]]
[[Gheorghe Ștefan]]
[[Diicul Buicescul]] | commander2 = {{flagicon|Moldavia|1646}} [[Vasile Lupu]]
[[File:Alex K Chmelnitskyi.svg|20px]] [[Tymofiy Khmelnytsky]] | commander3 = | units1 = | units2 = | units3 = | strength1 = 20-30,000 Wallachians, 5,000 allies | strength2 = 4,000 Moldavians,
15,000 Cossacks,
2,000 Tatars,
100 Germans | strength3 = | casualties1 = 1,000 Wallachians, 200 Poles and Lithuanians, 100 Serbs, 80 Hungarians | casualties2 = 3,000 Moldavians, 7,000 Cossacks, 1,000 Tatars, all Germans and Austrians killed, the rest captured | casualties3 = | notes = | campaignbox = }} The '''Battle of Finta''' (27 May 1653) was a confrontation between [[List of rulers of Wallachia|Prince]] [[Matei Basarab]]'s [[Wallachia]]n army and a combined [[Moldavia]]n–[[Cossack Hetmanate|Cossack]]–[[Crimean Khanate|Tatar]] force under [[List of rulers of Moldavia|Prince]] [[Vasile Lupu]] and [[Tymofiy Khmelnytsky]]. It took place around [[Finta, Dâmbovița|Finta]], now a [[Commune in Romania|commune]] in [[Dâmbovița County]], [[Romania]]. The battle began by an attack of [[Moldavian military forces|Moldavian infantry]] and Tatar–Cossack cavalrymen. From the beginning, the Moldavians, Tatars and Cossacks were driven back by the [[Wallachian military forces]] and Lithuanian defenders. Subsequently, both armies advanced to meet in a marshland, where a great [[melee]] began. Wallachians, Polish-Lithuanians, ''[[Seimeni]]'' Serb and Hungarian mercenaries destroyed the entire force of Cossacks and Tatars, with their swords and bayonets; the Moldavians, alongside the [[Holy Roman Empire|German and Austrian]] mercenaries, retreated a kilometer to prepare for the attacks. They resisted a series of attacks by the Wallachian-led combined troops, until finally the Wallachians bombarded their positions. The German and Austrian mercenaries were all killed during the bombardment. 1,000 Moldavians, 4,000 Cossacks and 1,000 Tatars were taken as prisoners, and mistreated by Wallachians. Almost half of them perished in captivity or were [[Slavery in Romania|sold as slaves]]. The battle was a Wallachian decisive victory, resulting in the ousting of the Moldavian Prince and his replacement with [[Gheorghe Ștefan]]. There was a brief Wallachian occupation of [[Iași]], and a siege of [[Suceava]] (where Tymofiy was killed). [[Category:1653 in Romania]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1653|Finta]] [[Category:Battles involving Wallachia|Finta]] [[Category:Battles involving Moldavia|Finta]] {{Romania-stub}} {{battle-stub}}

{{no footnotes|date=August 2009}} {{Infobox military conflict |image=Prise de la smalah d Abd-El-Kader a Taguin 16 mai 1843 Horace Vernet.jpg |image_size=300px |caption=''Capture of the Smala of Abd El-Kader, 16 May 1843'' by [[Horace Vernet]]. |conflict=Battle of the Smala |partof=the [[French conquest of Algeria]] |date=16 May 1843 |place=[[Zmalet El Emir Abdelkader|Taguin]], [[French Algeria]] |result=French victory |combatant1={{flagicon|France}} [[July Monarchy|Kingdom of France]] |combatant2=[[File:Dz flag-Abdelkader.png|23px]] [[Emirate of Abdelkader|Algerian resistance]] |commander1={{flagicon|France}} [[Henri d'Orléans, Duke of Aumale]] |commander2=[[File:Dz flag-Abdelkader.png|23px]] [[Abd al-Qadir al-Jaza'iri]] |strength1= 500 cavalry |strength2= 30,000 |casualties1=9 dead
12 wounded |casualties2=300 dead }} {{Campaignbox French conquest of Algeria}} The '''Battle of the Smala''' was fought in 1843 between [[France]] and [[Algeria]]n resistance fighters during the [[French conquest of Algeria]]. The French, led by [[Henri d'Orleans, duke of Aumale]], raided the encampment (known as a ''smala'' or ''zmelah'') of Algerian resistance leader [[Abd al-Qadir al-Jaza'iri|Abd al-Qadir]] on 16 May 1843, while al-Qadir was absent on a raiding expedition. The 500 French cavalrymen surprised the camp defenders, who fired a single volley before scattering. More than 3,000 of al-Qadir's followers (out of a camp population of 30,000) were captured, as were many of his possessions, including his warchest and a library valued at £5,000. Three days later, another 2,500 followers were captured. Al-Qadir fled to [[Morocco]] later that year, triggering French pressure on Morocco and the advent of the [[First Franco-Moroccan War]] in 1844. He was eventually captured in 1847, ending major Algerian resistance to the French colonial occupation. ==External links== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=xXYoAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA310&ots=KQd8WIA0H4&dq=Makta%20Trezel&pg=PA366#v=onepage&q=Aumale&f=false The Tricolor on the Atlas] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=iAgZAAAAYAAJ&dq=Taguin%20Algeria&pg=PA221#v=onepage&q=&f=false The life of Abdel Kader] {{coord|34.95|5.65|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Smala, Battle of}} [[Category:Battles involving France]] [[Category:Battles involving Algeria]] [[Category:French Algeria]] [[Category:1843 in Algeria]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1843]] [[Category:19th century in Africa]] [[Category:May 1843 events]] {{France-battle-stub}} {{Africa-hist-stub}}

'''Broadcast signal intrusion''' is the hijacking of [[Broadcasting|broadcast]] signals of [[Radio broadcasting|radio]], [[television station]]s, [[cable television]] broadcast feeds or satellite signals. Hijacking incidents have involved local TV and radio stations as well as cable and national networks. Although television, cable and satellite broadcast signal intrusions tend to receive more media coverage, radio station intrusions are more frequent, as many simply rebroadcast a signal received from another radio station. All that is required is an [[Transmitter|FM transmitter]] that can overpower the same frequency as the station being rebroadcast. Other methods that have been used in North America to intrude on legal broadcasts include breaking into the transmitter area and splicing audio directly into the feed.{{cite web | url = http://www.smpte-sbe48.org/oldnews/news1101.html | title = Tower Industry Part 11 – Tower Harassment | accessdate = 2007-04-25 | last = Kipp | first = Vicki W. }} As a [[cable television]] operator connects itself in the signal path between individual stations and the system's subscribers, broadcasters have fallen victim to signal tampering on cable systems on multiple occasions. == Confirmed events == === "Vrillon" on Southern Television === {{Main|Southern Television broadcast interruption}} On November 26, 1977, an audio message, purporting to come from outer space, was broadcast during an [[ITN]] news bulletin on [[Southern Television]] in the UK. The intrusion did not affect the video signal but replaced the programme audio with warnings as to the destiny of the human race and a disaster to affect "your world and the beings on other worlds around you". The [[Independent Broadcasting Authority|IBA]] confirmed that it was the first time such a transmission had been made. None of the individuals responsible for the intrusion have been identified, although some people believe that the message could have originated from an alien race.{{cite news|title=Source of hoax space broadcast stays a mystery|date=28 November 1977|work=The Times|pages=2, col. E}} === Captain Midnight on HBO === {{Main|Captain Midnight broadcast signal intrusion}} [[File:hbocaptainmidnight.jpg|thumb|right|MacDougall's message as seen by HBO viewers, behind the [[SMPTE color bars]].]] At 12:32 am [[North American Eastern Time Zone|Eastern Time]] on April 27, 1986, [[HBO]] (Home Box Office) had its satellite signal feed from its operations center on [[Long Island]] in [[Hauppauge, New York]] interrupted by a man calling himself "Captain Midnight". The interruption occurred during a presentation of ''[[The Falcon and the Snowman]]''. The intrusion lasted between 4 and 5 minutes and was seen by viewers along the East Coast. The man, who during the interruption also threatened to hijack the signals of [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] and [[The Movie Channel]], was later caught and identified as John R. MacDougall of [[Ocala, Florida]]. He was prosecuted shortly thereafter. Authorities were tipped off by a man from [[Wisconsin]] in a phone booth at a rest area off [[Interstate 75 in Florida|Interstate 75]] in [[Gainesville, Florida]]. The man filing the report said that he overheard MacDougall bragging about it. MacDougall's guilt was confirmed by an FCC investigation that showed he was alone at Central Florida Teleport at the time of the incident and a recording of the jamming video showed that the text was created by a [[character generator]] at that location. He was charged with transmitting without a radio license in violation of {{UnitedStatesCode|47|301}}. MacDougall pleaded guilty and was fined $5,000 and served a year probation. Ambiguity about whether the 47 USC 301 charge was applicable since the transmitter had a license resulted in the passage of {{UnitedStatesCode|18|1367}} which made satellite jamming a [[felony]]. MacDougall was able to perform the intrusion while working a second job as a master control operator at a satellite [[Earth station#Telecommunications port|teleport]] in Florida, where he worked to make ends meet due to declining income from his satellite TV equipment business. He stated that he did it because he was frustrated with HBO's service rates, and that it was hurting his business selling satellite dishes (hence his second job at the teleport). The message, placed over [[SMPTE color bars]], broadcast by MacDougall read: {{Clear}}{{quote|
GOODEVENING HBO
FROM CAPTAIN MIDNIGHT
$12.95/MONTH ?
NO WAY !
[SHOWTIME/MOVIE CHANNEL BEWARE!]
}} === "Religious" takeover === Playboy's satellite network was intentionally "jammed" with a text-only message on the night of Sunday, September 6, 1987. The message read, "Thus sayeth the Lord thy God. Remember the Sabbath and keep it holy. Repent for the kingdom of Heaven is at hand." (The verses were taken from Exodus 20:8 and Matthew 4:17 in the Bible.) The white text and black background of the message prevented viewers from seeing the movie that Playboy was running at the time called ''Three Daughters''. (Playboy's feed was on RCA Satcom 4, transponder 24.) Thomas Haynie of Virginia Beach, Virginia was convicted of satellite piracy in September 1990 in Norfolk, Virginia federal court in connection with the incident. Haynie was an uplink engineer at the Christian Broadcasting Network, a television ministry in Virginia Beach. He was on duty at the time of the jamming.{{cite web|url=https://law.resource.org/pub/us/case/reporter/F2/940/940.F2d.653.91-5000.html|title=940 F.2d 653|publisher=|accessdate=27 December 2016}} According to investigators, it was the religious content of the transmission and the type of equipment used that drew them to CBN. The jamming signal left behind subtle technical clues that were captured on a VHS recording made at Playboy's uplink at the time of the event – like finding "fingerprints" in the video. After investigators were confident that they identified the brand of transmitter and character generator from the video, they concluded that CBN was the culprit. CBN maintained that the FCC's case was entirely circumstantial since there were no witnesses and the signal could not be traced to a point of origin. During the investigation, experts on both sides attempted to recreate the incident with CBN's equipment. According to CBN spokesman Dino McCann they were unsuccessful.{{cite web|url=http://articles.dailypress.com/1990-05-24/news/9005240158_1_cbn-mr-christian-broadcasting-network|title=Trial Set In Jamming Of Playboy Channel|publisher=|accessdate=27 December 2016}} Furthermore, CBN asserted that there was not enough power for Haynie to jam Playboy's signal but during the trial, government witnesses said the CBN station was capable of interfering with satellite transmissions.{{cite web|url=http://articles.dailypress.com/1990-09-25/news/9009300294_1_verdict-playboy-channel-jury|title=Federal Jury Convicts Cbn Technician|publisher=|accessdate=27 December 2016}} After initially being deadlocked, the jury eventually sided with the prosecution and convicted Haynie on two of six counts (Haynie was also accused of interfering with the American Exxxtacy channel on GTE Spacenet 1 on the same date; however, a recording of the event was of such poor quality that it was unusable and Haynie was acquitted of the associated charges). Haynie received three years of probation, a $1000 fine, and 150 hours of community service. Haynie has always maintained his innocence. === Max Headroom incident === [[File:Max Headroom broadcast signal intrusion.jpg|right|thumb|Screen shot of the Max Headroom hijacker.]] {{Main|Max Headroom broadcast signal intrusion}} On November 22, 1987, an unidentified man wearing a [[Max Headroom (character)|Max Headroom]] mask appeared on the signals of two television stations in [[Chicago]]. [[Independent station]] [[WGN-TV]], owned by [[Tribune Broadcasting]], was hijacked first. The intrusion occurred during the sports report on its 9:00 pm newscast and lasted about 25 seconds. Then came [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] station [[WTTW]], where the man was seen and heard uttering garbled remarks before dropping his [[trousers]], partially exposing his [[buttocks]], and was then spanked with a flyswatter before the screen went black. The next interception occurred at about 11:00 pm during an episode of the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' serial, "[[Horror of Fang Rock]]", and lasted almost 90 seconds. None of the individuals responsible for the intrusion have been identified. This incident got the attention of the [[CBS Evening News]] the next day and was talked about nationwide. The HBO incident was also mentioned in the same news report. === "Telewizja Solidarność" (TV Solidarity) === In September 1985, four astronomers at [[Poland]]'s [[University of Toruń]], Zygmunt Turło, Leszek Zaleski, Piotr Łukaszewski and Jan Hanasz, used a home computer, a synchronizing circuit, and a transmitter to superimpose messages in support of the labor movement Solidarność ([[Solidarity (Polish trade union)|Solidarity]]) over state-run television broadcasts in Toruń, including an episode of ''[[07 zgłoś się]]''. The messages read "''Dość podwyżek cen, kłamstw i represji. Solidarność Toruń''" ("Enough price increases, lies, and repressions. Solidarity Toruń") and "''Bojkot wyborów naszym obowiązkiem.''" ("It is our duty to [[election boycott|boycott the election]]", referring to the [[Polish legislative election, 1985|rigged Sejm elections of 1985]]) with the Solidarity logo.{{cite web |url=http://w.icm.edu.pl/tvS/tvs.htm |title=(polish) |publisher=W.icm.edu.pl |date=2006-05-18 |accessdate=2009-07-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091206064447/http://w.icm.edu.pl/tvS/tvs.htm |archivedate=2009-12-06 |df= }} The four men were eventually discovered and were charged with "possession of an unlicensed radio transmitter and publication of materials that could cause public unrest". At their sentencing, the judge noted their prize winning work in the Polish scientific community and gave each of them probation and a fine of the equivalent of US$100 each (or 3,000,000 old złoty, 300 [[Polish złoty|PLN]] in today's currency).{{cite web |url=http://w.icm.edu.pl/tvS/pirat.htm |title=(english) |publisher=W.icm.edu.pl |date=1985-09-14 |accessdate=2009-07-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326080522/http://w.icm.edu.pl/tvS/pirat.htm |archivedate=2009-03-26 |df= }} === The era of Soviet pirate broadcasting === Broadcast signal intrusion was a common practice in the [[USSR]] during the 1970s and 1980s due to the absence of and high demand for any non-government broadcasting.{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/1984/0118/011818.html/(page)/2|title='Lords' and 'Knights' defy Soviet authority, 'pollute' the airwaves |date=January 18, 1984|work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|accessdate=8 January 2014}} As early as 1966, there was a report of an incident in the city of [[Kaluga]] where an 18 year old broadcast a hoax announcement that nuclear war had broken out with the United States.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19660929&id=UNQiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2ycEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7175,5708798&hl=en|title=Soviet 'Pirate Radios' Spark Government Ire|date=September 29, 1966|work=[[The Milkawaukee Journal]]|accessdate=23 January 2016}} In the mid-1970s so many pirates were operating around the city of [[Arkhangelsk]], especially at night, that local people were urged to telephone reports of violators to a special number. Hijackers using call signs such as "cucumber", "Radio Millimeter", "Green Goat", "Fortune", and others, would overpower the signal on [[Airborne radio relay|relay stations]] for wired radio networks in order to transmit their own programming, or transmit into wired radio networks during gaps in normal programming. Even though the incidents appear to have been fairly common according to reports from the [[BBC]], most were not publicly acknowledged for policy reasons. Reports in newspapers typically referred to the hijackers as "radio hooligans broadcasting drivel, rudeness, vulgarity, uncensored expressions, and trashy music". State news organizations also attempted smear campaigns against such pirate broadcasters, claiming that they had interfered with a state frequency used by [[Aeroflot]], "preventing a doctor in an air ambulance from transmitting information about a patient". === 2006 Lebanon War === During the [[2006 Lebanon War]], Israel overloaded the satellite transmission of [[Hezbollah]]'s [[Al Manar TV]] to broadcast anti-Hezbollah [[propaganda]]. One spot showed Hezbollah leader [[Hassan Nasrallah]] with crosshairs superimposed on his image followed by three gunshots and a voice saying "Your day is coming" and shots of the [[Israeli Air Force]] destroying targets in [[Lebanon]].{{cite web | url = http://www.psywar.org/israellebanon.php | title = Psychological Operations during the Israel-Lebanon War 2006 | first= Herbert |last= Friedman | accessdate = 2008-08-17 }} === "The Winker's Song" incident === In June and July 2017, [[Mansfield 103.2 FM]], a local radio station in the UK, had its signal intruded at least eight times during outside broadcasts. During these intrusions, "[[The Winker's Song (Misprint)]]" was played. The perpetrator has not been identified.{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-nottinghamshire-40559523 | title = Mansfield radio station hit by 'winker' song hijacker | accessdate = 2017-07-17 }} == Other incidents == === Television signal intrusions === On an unknown date in 1989, an advert on [[TVQ|TVQ-10]] in [[Brisbane]], [[Australia]] was interrupted with interference from radio station [[4MMM|FM104]]. https://m.youtube.com/watch?list=PLk4dmv7qHN1c3h-SkWeUJ5xGsoBCCFtME&v=tmsPxGaG2Sc On January 3, 2007 in Australia, during a broadcast of an episode of the [[Canadians|Canadian]] television series ''[[Mayday (Canadian TV series)|Mayday]]'' (known in Australia as ''Air Crash Investigation'') on the [[Seven Network]], an audio signal unexpectedly started playing, clearly saying in an American accent, "Jesus Christ, help us all, Lord." This same voice message continued to repeat itself over and over during the show for a total of six minutes. A spokesman for Seven later denied that the transmission was a prank or a security breach and claimed that the repeated line was actually part of the original broadcast and said, "Jesus Christ, one of the Nazarenes", although there is hardly any similarity between the two phrases. Subsequent investigation by independent researchers revealed that the invading transmission was actually from a videotaped news broadcast of a civilian truck being ambushed in Iraq. It remains unknown whether or not this was an intentional act of television piracy or a genuine glitch of some sort.{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/mystery-video-audio-dynamite/news-story/50690012f5a66b7369e069d7fc15dfca|title=Mystery video audio dynamite|date=4 January 2007|publisher=|accessdate=27 December 2016}}[http://danwarne.com/was-channel-7-hacked-by-jesus/ Was Channel 7 hacked by Jesus?] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070206101308/http://danwarne.com/was-channel-7-hacked-by-jesus/ |date=February 6, 2007 }} On June 17, 2007, an intrusion incident occurred on [[Czech Television]]'s Sunday morning programme ''Panorama'', which shows panoramic shots of [[Prague]] and various locations across the [[Czech Republic|country]], especially mountain resorts. One of the cameras, located in [[Černý Důl]] in [[Krkonoše]], had been tampered with on-site and its video stream was replaced with the hackers' own, which contained [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]] of a small nuclear explosion in the local landscape, ending in [[white noise]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MzaN2x8qXcM|title=Czech nuclear bomb prank hoax|first=|last=Don82CZ|date=17 June 2007|publisher=|accessdate=27 December 2016|via=YouTube}} The broadcast looked authentic enough; the only clue for the viewers was the [[URL|Web address]] of the artist group [[Ztohoven]], which had already performed several [[reality hacking]] incidents before. Czech Television considered legal action against the group, and tourism workers in the area expressed outrage (since the programme serves to promote tourism in the areas shown).{{cite web | url = http://aktualne.centrum.cz/kultura/umeni/clanek.phtml?id=448450 | title = Umělci napadli vysílání ČT 2. Podívejte se jak | accessdate = 2007-06-17 | last = Wohlmuth | first = Radek | language = Czech }} On July 13, 2007, a grainy photo of a man and woman interrupted [[Washington, D.C.]] [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] affiliate [[WJLA]]'s digital or [[High-definition television|HD]] signal. The picture was not transmitted over the analog signal, however. The incident was deemed a genuine signal intrusion by various websites but has since been confirmed to be the result of an older [[HDTV]] [[encoder]] malfunctioning in the early morning hours and going undetected. Station management stated that the image was from an advertisement for ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]''.{{cite web | url = http://www.tvpredictions.com/wjla071307.htm | title = Washington DC TV Station 'Hijacked' By Mystery Photo (archive.org) | accessdate = 2007-07-13 | last = Swann | first = Phillip |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070716163040/http://www.tvpredictions.com/wjla071307.htm |archivedate = 2007-07-16}} On February 11, 2013, [[Great Falls, Montana]] [[CBS]] affiliate [[KRTV]] had their [[Emergency Alert System]] hijacked with an audible message warning viewers that "dead bodies are rising from their graves".{{cite web |url=http://gawker.com/5983516/montana-tv-stations-emergency-alert-system-hacked-warns-of-zombie-apocalypse |title=Montana TV Station's Emergency Alert System Hacked, Warns of Zombie Apocalypse |accessdate=2012-02-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130213221612/http://gawker.com/5983516/montana-tv-stations-emergency-alert-system-hacked-warns-of-zombie-apocalypse |archivedate=2013-02-13 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/local-montana-station-breaks-into-programming-with-emergency-zombie-apocalypse-alert/|title=Local Station Breaks Into Programming With Emergency Zombie Apocalypse Alert|last=Howerton|first=Jason|date=11 February 2013|publisher=[[Mediaite]]|accessdate=12 February 2013}} Later the same night in [[Marquette, Michigan]], the same type of hijacking and reference to a "zombie invasion" was made over the EAS systems of ABC affiliate [[WBUP]] and PBS member station [[WNMU (TV)|WNMU]] during primetime programming.{{cite web|url=http://www.uppermichiganssource.com/news/story.aspx?id=859352#.URnFMDvfLHR|title=Emergency Broadcast System hacked|date=11 February 2013|publisher=[[WLUC-TV]]|accessdate=12 February 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://abc10up.com/abc-10-victim-of-hackers/|title=ABC 10 victim of hackers|last=Thompson|first=Cynthia|date=11 February 2013|publisher=[[WBUP]]|accessdate=12 February 2013}} Shortly afterwards, PBS affiliate [[KENW (TV)|KENW]] of [[Portales, New Mexico]] was struck with a similar hacking incident, repeating similar information regarding zombies;{{cite web|url=http://www.mediabistro.com/tvspy/eas-zombie-alert-hits-more-stations-finger-pointing-over-how-it-happened-begins_b80550|title=EAS Zombie Alert Hits More Stations. Finger Pointing Over How it Happened Begins|publisher=|accessdate=27 December 2016}} however, this led to the arrest of the hacker of the four television stations.http://abc10up.com/update-eas-hacker-found/ The audio clip from this hack was also used in the track "[[Fight 'Em 'Til You Can't]]" by [[Anthrax (American band)|Anthrax]]. === Cable network feed intrusions === On May 1, 2007, a [[Comcast]] [[cable television headend|headend]] replaced the [[Disney Channel]]'s program ''[[Handy Manny]]'' with hard-core [[pornography]] for viewers in [[Lincroft, New Jersey]]. Comcast stated it was conducting an investigation into the event's cause but did not announce findings to the public.{{cite web|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070917191530/http://cbs4.com/topstories/local_story_122080846.html|archive-date=17 September 2007|url=http://cbs4.com/topstories/local_story_122080846.html|date=3 May 2007|title=Disney Channel Horror: Customers Get Porn Instead|publisher=CBS4.com}}{{cite web|title=New Jersey Kids See Porn Instead of Cartoons on Disney Channel|date=3 May 2007|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2007/05/03/new-jersey-kids-see-porn-instead-cartoons-on-disney-channel/|work=Foxnews.com}} On February 1, 2009, another Comcast headend, in [[Tucson, Arizona]], replaced [[NBC]] affiliate [[KVOA]]'s signal with graphic footage from the [[pornography|pornographic]] video ''Wild Cherries 5'' in portions of [[Arizona]] for ten seconds{{Failed verification|date=July 2012|talk=Super Bowl broadcast time mismatch}}, interrupting [[Super Bowl XLIII]] between the [[Arizona Cardinals]] and the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] during the fourth quarter. Comcast claimed "Our initial investigation suggests this was an isolated malicious act. We are conducting a thorough investigation to determine who was behind this." KVOA also announced that it will be investigating the incident.[http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Porn-Clip-Interrupts-Super-Bowl-Broadcast-In-Tucson-Arizona-Fans-Exposed-To-X-Rated-Movie-Scene/Article/200902115215795?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Feature_Teaser_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_15215795_Porn_Clip_Interrupts_Super_Bowl_Broadcast_In_Tucson%2C_Arizona%3A_Fans_Exposed_To_X-Rated_Movie_Scene Super Bowl Cut Off By Porn Scene], [[Sky News]], February 3, 2009{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7864733.stm | title = Super Bowl porn hits US viewers | accessdate = 2009-02-02 | last = Unknown | first = Unknown | work=BBC News | date=2009-02-02}} On February 4, 2011, former Cox Cable employee Frank Tanori Gonzalez was arrested by the FBI and local police in relation to the case.{{cite web|url=http://azstarnet.com/news/local/crime/article_c7501862-30c4-11e0-8cc4-001cc4c03286.html|title=Man arrested in connection with airing of porn clip during 2009 Super Bowl|first=Kim Smith ARIZONA DAILY|last=STAR|publisher=|accessdate=27 December 2016}} On April 20, 2012, three minutes of a gay pornographic film was broadcast during a morning news show on [[CHCH-DT|CHCH TV]] in [[Hamilton, Ontario]], Canada for [[Shaw Communications|Shaw cable]] viewers. The night before, a cable was cut; while it was being fixed on the morning of the incident, the adult programming was spliced into CHCH's feed.{{cite web|url=http://www.thespec.com/news/local/article/708898--porn-movie-overtakes-ch-broadcast|title=Oops! A morning news broadcast to remember|date=21 April 2012|publisher=|accessdate=27 December 2016|via=The Hamilton Spectator}}[http://www.torontosun.com/2012/04/20/hamilton-ont-news-station-broadcasts-gay-porn Hamilton, Ont., news station broadcasts gay porn] === Satellite feed intrusions === On September 18, 2012, the [[Disney Channel]] once again was interrupted on the [[Dish Network]], replacing 6 minutes of ''[[Lilo & Stitch]]'' with a portion of a hardcore pornographic movie. The incident was reported to [[Dish Network]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/children-accidentally-porn-footage-lilo-stitch-broadcast-article-1.1162514#ixzz26vTPFC2Y|title=Kids exposed to porn on N.C. Dish Disney channel|publisher=|accessdate=27 December 2016}} On March 11, 2016, private satellite dish owners in Israel watching ''[[HaAh HaGadol]]'' on [[Channel 2 (Israel)|Channel 2]] had their viewing of adventures of house-bound reality stars interrupted with incitement from Hamas. The disruption lasted a little over three and a half minutes.{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/hamas-hacks-israeli-tv-the-terror-will-never-end/|title=Watch: Hamas hacks into Israeli TV and threatens: 'Terror will never end'|publisher=|accessdate=27 December 2016}} On March 5, 2017, the broadcast of a Libyan television station was interrupted by Gaddafists.https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=QwjAZGoGjPo == See also == * [[Pirate radio]] * [[Pirate television]] * [[Culture jamming]] * [[Radio jamming]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h5mzkt4N77s CBS News report on Max Headroom Chicago Takeover] at [[YouTube]] * [http://bloguje.czechtek.net/552348-statement-made-by-art-group-ztohoven-regarding-their-attack-at-the-public-service-broadcaster-in-the-czech-republic.php Statement made by art group ZTOHOVEN regarding their attack at the public service broadcaster in the Czech Republic] * [http://bloguje.czechtek.net/551695-an-artistic-group-interfered-with-the-czech-tv-broadcast-with-fictitious-nuclear-explosion.php An artistic group interfered with the Czech TV broadcast with fictitious nuclear explosion] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lztemas2fFI Video of the "Telewizja Solidarność" signal intrusions] at [[YouTube]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090326080522/http://w.icm.edu.pl/tvS/pirat.htm Polish Tv pirate ] (This page has moved) {{Culture jamming}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Broadcast Signal Intrusion}} [[Category:Federal Communications Commission]] [[Category:Satellite television]] [[Category:Cable television]] [[Category:Broadcast engineering]] [[Category:Security]]

Constitution of the Republic of the Congo
Craft, Tourism, Agricultural, Commercial and Industrial Fair of Lagoa

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=March 2009}}
The '''FATACIL''' ({{lang-pt|'''Feira de Artesanato, Turismo, Agricultura, Comércio e Indústria de Lagoa'''}}), the ''Craft, Tourism, Agricultural, Commercial and Industrial Fair of Lagoa'', occurs annually (since 1980) for 10 days in August in the ''Parque de Feiras e Exposições'' (''Fair and Exhibition Grounds'') in [[Algarve|Algarvan]] city of [[Lagoa (Algarve)]].
The fair is attended each year by thousands of visitors from all parts of the country (the last few years the attendance has been about 180,000), not only because of their interest in promoting traditional arts and crafts which are on the edge of extinction, but also for the shows which occur daily.
Recently there have been about 800 exhibitors of various products including the arts and crafts of Portugal generally, and of the Algarve in particular: articles made of everything from [[textile]]s to [[copper]] and [[forge]]d [[iron]]; [[lace]]work; artifacts made of [[wood]]; [[pottery]] and [[ceramic art|ceramics]]; [[cork (material)|cork]] items; [[basket]] work; or the typical Algarve [[puppet]]s of [[Martim Longo]] and [[Querença]].
==External links== * [http://www.cometoportugal.com/fatacil-fair%20lagoa.html Cometoportugal.com: '''FATACIL''' (Craft, Tourism, Agricultural, Commercial and Industrial Fair of Lagoa) website]

{{For|the 30 Rock character|Danny Baker (character)}} {{distinguish|Danny Bakker (disambiguation){{!}}Danny Bakker}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Use British English|date=May 2013}} {{lead too short|date=June 2010}} {{Infobox person | name = Danny Baker | image = Danny Baker.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Baker in 2012 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1957|6|22|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Deptford]], [[London]], England | height = | weight = | known = | occupation = [[Radio DJ]], [[Television presenter|presenter]], [[journalist]] | salary = | death_place = | spouse = Wendy Baker | website = | module = <center>{{Listen|embed=yes|filename=Danny Baker BBC Radio4 Desert Island Discs 31 Jul 2007 b012wcl4.flac|title=<center>Danny Baker's voice</center>|type=speech|description=<center>[[:File:Danny Baker BBC Radio4 Desert Island Discs 31 Jul 2007 b012wcl4.flac|Recorded July 2007]] from the BBC Radio 4 programme ''[[Desert Island Discs]]''</center>}}</center> }}
'''Danny<!-- DO NOT change this to Daniel. His name is Danny, and it's NOT short for Daniel, as he has made clear several times. --> Baker'''<ref>Free BMD Births September 1957 - BAKER, Danny, Mother's Maiden Name: Ward, District: Deptford, Vol 5c, Page 404.</ref> (born 22 June 1957) is an English [[comedy writer]], [[journalist]], [[radio DJ]] and [[screenwriter]]. Since the late 1970s, he has worked for a wide range of publications and broadcasters including ''[[NME]]'', [[LWT]], the [[BBC]] and [[talksport|Talk Radio]].
== Early life == Baker was born in [[Deptford]] in south east London to Fred "Spud" Baker, a [[Stevedore|dockworker]], and Betty, a factory worker. He grew up in [[Bermondsey]]. He attended [[Rotherhithe]] Primary School and then instead of taking up a [[grammar school]] place he went to the nearby West Greenwich Secondary Boys School, Deptford.<ref name=Autobiography>{{cite book|date=6 November 2012|first=Danny |last=Baker|isbn=978-0297863403|title= Going to Sea in a Sieve: The Autobiography |publisher=Weidenfeld & Nicolson}}</ref> He left the school in April 1972 at the age of 14 and initially worked in One Stop Records, a small but fashionable record shop in South Molton Street in the [[West End of London]].<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://downloads.bbc.co.uk/podcasts/radio4/did/did_20110731-1200a.mp3 |title=Podcast of Baker being interviewed for the BBC radio series Desert Island Discs |work=BBC Radio 4 |accessdate=29 August 2011}}</ref> The youngest of three children, he has an older sister, Sharon, and had an older brother, Michael, who died aged 29 when Danny was 24.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/a-few-quiet-words-with-danny-baker-boy-1274806.html|title=A few quiet words with Danny Baker boy|date=1997-03-24|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-02-09|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==Career== ===Print journalism=== In 1977, Baker started writing for the punk fanzine ''[[Sniffin' Glue]]'' which was founded by his old schoolfriend [[Mark Perry (musician)|Mark Perry]] which in turn led to an offer from the ''[[New Musical Express]]'', then edited by [[Nick Logan]]. Baker began working as the office receptionist, but was soon contributing regular articles and reviews before progressing to interviews. He often refers to these times during his [[Radio programming|radio shows]], regularly citing examples of the ridiculous behaviour exhibited by his rock star interviewees.
In the later 1990s, Baker wrote a weekly sports column for ''[[The Times]]'' and was briefly a columnist for early issues of film magazine ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]''.
===Television=== ====Reporting for LWT (1980s)==== Baker started his TV career in 1980 at [[London Weekend Television]] (LWT), as the presenter of ''Twentieth Century Box'' - a series of regional documentaries on elements of [[youth culture]] in London, produced by [[Janet Street Porter]]. One edition in the first series documented the burgeoning [[new wave of British heavy metal]] ([[NWOBHM]]) scene, including an early TV appearance of [[Iron Maiden]] performing at [[The Marquee Club]] and interviews with "[[air guitar]]ists". Other editions also featured early appearances from the likes of [[Spandau Ballet]] and [[Depeche Mode]].
Baker's first mainstream break was as [[wikt:itinerant|roving]] [[reporter]]-[[Television presenter|presenter]] on the [[Michael Aspel]] [[LWT]] regional magazine ''[[The Six O'Clock Show]]'' alongside former ''[[Mastermind (TV series)|Mastermind]]'' winner and former London [[Hackney carriage|black cab]] driver [[Fred Housego]]. [[Paul Ross]] (brother of Jonathan Ross whom Baker had as his [[best man]]) was his researcher. During his stint on ''[[The Six O'Clock Show]]'', Baker was filmed having an altercation with a British Rail press officer. This clip is often resurrected for [[clip show]]s and can be seen on YouTube.
====Writing and presenting (early–late 1990s)==== Baker appeared regularly on LWT's regional output during the 1980s and early 1990s - working on such programmes as ''Six O'Clock Live'', ''Danny Baker's Londoners'', and in 1991, ''The Game'' - a six-part series which featured coverage of teams involved in the fourth division of the East London [[Sunday league football|Sunday Football League]]. The series was later released on DVD.<ref>http://www.shortlist.com/entertainment/sport/danny-baker-the-game-football-tv</ref>
Baker began writing for television programmes in 1992 after being asked to prepare a piece for one of the first [[archive clip show]]s: ''[[TV Hell]]'', which was a collection of the worst TV programmes ever. Since then he has presented television shows such as ''[[Win, Lose, or Draw]]'', ''[[Pets Win Prizes]]'' and ''TV Heroes'', which was a series of 10-minute homages to some of Baker's entertainment idols including [[Fanny Cradock]], [[Peter Glaze]] (from ''[[Crackerjack (TV series)|Crackerjack]]'') and the ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' audience. In one episode of ''TV Heroes'', a clip was shown of Baker leaping around to a performance of "Ooh What A Life" by the [[Gibson Brothers]] in 1979, which was captioned as "Danny Baker's first TV appearance". During an edition of his own later series "TV Heroes" featuring the audiences from Top Of The Pops, Baker described himself as "looking like he was trying to put out a small fire".
Baker also began a BBC Saturday night [[Talk show|chat show]], called ''Danny Baker After All'' which borrowed its style from ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]'', but his style and guests ([[Rick Wakeman]] of prog rock band [[Yes (band)|Yes]] was a regular) did not attract the mainstream audience the slot demanded. Film critic [[Mark Kermode]]'s band The Railtown Bottlers was the show's house band.<ref name="railtown">{{cite news |title=My 20-year love affair with the joy of skiffle|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/jun/01/popandrock2|accessdate=20 February 2011 | location=London |newspaper=The Guardian|first=Mark|last=Kermode|date=1 June 2008}}</ref>
Later he fronted television adverts for [[Daz (detergent)|Daz washing powder]] and [[Mars bar]] confectionery. Baker parodied his Daz ads by appearing as himself on the sitcom ''[[Me, You and Him]]''.
During this period, Baker began presenting on [[BBC Radio 5 (former)|BBC Radio 5]]'s ''[[606 (radio show)|606]]'' football-related phone-in programme as well as the job of presenting ''Match of the Eighties'', a six-part BBC series of football during the [[1980-81 in English football|1980/81]] and [[1985-86 in English football|1985/86]] seasons.
Baker was a writer on Chris Evans' ''[[TFI Friday]]'' show, as well as contributing material for presenters such as [[Angus Deayton]] and [[Jonathan Ross]].
====Guest appearances (late 1990s–2000s)==== During the late 1990s he made guest appearances on comedy shows including ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'', ''[[Shooting Stars (TV series)|Shooting Stars]]'' and ''[[Room 101 (TV series)|Room 101]]''. During this period he appeared in the press as a result of nights out with friends [[Chris Evans (presenter)|Chris Evans]] and England footballer [[Paul Gascoigne]]. Gascoigne was under media scrutiny for drinking and socialising while preparing for tournaments. After Gascoigne was left out of the [[1998 World Cup]] squad, Baker went on ''Have I Got News For You'' to defend his friend and criticise the omission.
He also appeared on ''[[The Terry and Gaby Show]]'' from 2003 to 2004 (where he burnt his hand trying to perform a trick with a microwave and a piece of soap) and has appeared on [[BBC Two]] quiz show ''[[QI]]'', becoming the show's first ever winner. Baker worked again with Charles Shaar Murray on the [[Ramones]] documentary ''End of the Century: The Story of the Ramones'', providing an audio commentary.
More recent TV projects include ''[[The Sitcom Showdown]]'' which began on [[Gold (UK TV channel)|UKTV Gold]] in April 2006, a 2014 show featuring archived television footage for BBC4 named ''Brushing Up On...'' and a music discussion show for BBC4 named ''Danny Baker's Rockin' Decades''. He also did ''[[Comic Relief Does The Apprentice]]'' in 2007 for [[Comic Relief (charity)|Comic Relief]]. He also starred in ''[[The Rocky Horror Show]]'', as the narrator, at the [[Churchill Theatre]] in [[Bromley]] and the [[New Wimbledon Theatre]].
Baker was announced as part of [[BT Sport]]'s football coverage in 2013, hosting a Friday evening show with [[Danny Kelly (journalist)|Danny Kelly]].<ref name="BT Sport">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/jun/03/bt-sport-danny-baker-danny-kelly-premier-league|title=BT Sport to reunite Danny Baker and Danny Kelly for football show|newspaper=The Guardian|date=3 June 2013|accessdate=2 August 2013}}</ref> In 2016, [[Chris Evans (presenter)|Chris Evans]] hired Baker to work as a writer on the 2016 series of ''[[Top Gear (2002 TV series)|Top Gear]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.list.co.uk/article/81033-chris-evans-hires-top-gear-comedy-writer/|title=Chris Evans hires Top Gear comedy writer|work=[[The List (magazine)|The List]]|date=28 May 2016|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> In November 2016, he entered as a latecomer in [[reality television]] show, ''[[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out Of Here]]'', along with [[Martin Roberts (presenter)|Martin Roberts]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/imacelebrity/highlights/welcome-to-danny-martin |title=Danny & Martin arrive in Camp |work=ITV.com |date=17 November 2016 |accessdate=1 January 2017}}</ref> Baker was the first person to be voted off in the series.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Agius|first1=Nicola|title=First I'm A Celebrity elimination results revealed|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/danny-baker-eliminated-im-celebrity-9337687 |newspaper=[[Daily Mirror]] |accessdate=25 November 2016|date=25 November 2016}}</ref>
===Radio career=== ====BBC GLR/5 Live/Radio 1 (1989{{ndash}}1997)==== Baker began his radio career on [[BBC GLR]] in 1989, presenting ''Weekend Breakfast'' from 6{{nbsp}} to 9{{nbsp}}am on Saturdays and Sundays. The show was produced by [[Chris Evans (British broadcaster)|Chris Evans]], who became a good friend to Baker. With GLR eventually opting for a more orthodox breakfast show at weekends, Baker moved to the 10{{nbsp}}am to 1{{nbsp}}pm slot on Sundays.
In 1990, Baker joined the newly launched [[BBC Radio 5 (former)|BBC Radio 5]], presenting ''Sportscall'', a phone-in sports quiz broadcast every Saturday lunchtime.
From October 1991 to October 1992 he presented ''[[606 (radio show)|606]]'' and, from February 1992 until October 1993, he presented ''Morning Edition'' from 6:30 to 9:30{{nbsp}}am every weekday morning. The show blended Baker's love of unusual trivia with 'grown-up' music. This was where Baker first teamed up with [[Danny Kelly (journalist)|Danny Kelly]] and Allis Moss. [[Mark Kermode]] added weekly film reviews, and would later appear with his band 'The Railtown Bottlers' every week on the first series of Baker's TV show.<ref name="railtown" />
Baker joined [[BBC Radio 1]] in October 1993, taking over the weekend mid-morning show from 10{{nbsp}}am to 1{{nbsp}}pm from [[Dave Lee Travis]] who had resigned on air following the sackings instigated by [[Matthew Bannister]] and [[Trevor Dann]] during the early 1990s. However, due to poor ratings, from November 1994 he was heard on Saturdays only from 10{{nbsp}}am to 12 noon. [[Simon Mayo]] took over Sunday mornings.
Baker's style led to a fall in listeners at Radio 1 but despite his tendering his resignation on at least two occasions, management added extensions to his contract. From October 1995, his Saturday show went out from 12:30 to 2:30{{nbsp}}pm. He left the station in September 1996. His co-hosts during this period included BBC continuity announcer Allis Moss, Dr. H, Laurie Sore, Andy Darling and [[Danny Kelly (journalist)|Danny Kelly]].
While continuing with his Saturday morning show on [[BBC Radio 1]], in 1996 Baker joined [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] to present a Sunday lunchtime show with [[Danny Kelly (journalist)|Danny Kelly]], ''Baker & Kelly Upfront''.
On leaving [[BBC Radio 1]], Baker returned to [[BBC GLR]] to present a three-hour Sunday show from 10{{nbsp}}am to 1{{nbsp}}pm. 'Baker and Kelly Upfront' also returned, now at Saturday lunchtime, while Baker also took on a new show, 'The Baker Line', a Wednesday evening version of the ''[[606 (radio show)|606]]'' phone-in show.
While 'Baker and Kelly Upfront' was light-hearted, 'The Baker Line' was darker and emotionally charged. Baker was at his most outspoken, and in early 1997, he was sacked from [[BBC Radio 5 Live|5 Live]] when station bosses alleged that he had incited threatening behaviour during an angry outburst about a referee.<ref name="independent">{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/danny-baker-theres-this-idea-that-i-talk-too-much-657252.html |title=Arts: Danny Baker - 'There's this idea that I talk too much' |newspaper=The Independent |date=13 April 2002 |accessdate=29 August 2011 |location=London |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110123065233/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/danny-baker-theres-this-idea-that-i-talk-too-much-657252.html |archivedate=23 January 2011}}</ref>
====Talk Radio/Virgin Radio (1998{{ndash}}2000)==== Baker joined [[TalkSPORT|Talk Radio]] to present a similar football phone-in with Kelly each Saturday from 5:30 to 7:30{{nbsp}}pm. A pre-match show was added from 11:30{{nbsp}}am to 1{{nbsp}}pm. After moving to the Saturday breakfast slot (8{{nbsp}}am to 12 noon), he engineered his own dismissal after a matter of weeks by refusing to centre the show on football, preferring to intersperse chat with his own music selections.
After leaving [[talkSPORT|Talk Radio]], he joined [[Virgin Radio (UK)|Virgin Radio]] in early 1999, taking over from [[Jonathan Ross (television presenter)|Jonathan Ross]] on Sundays from 10{{nbsp}}am to 1{{nbsp}}pm.
Not long after, Baker was approached by the [[BBC]] and was asked whether he wanted to present a Saturday morning show on [[BBC Radio 2]]. Baker turned down the offer by saying "the time wasn't right", and the show was given to Ross. Baker also deputised on Virgin's Saturday lunchtime football show from 12 noon to 2{{nbsp}}pm for a handful of shows, alongside [[Danny Kelly (journalist)|Danny Kelly]] until he left the station in 2000.
====BBC London 94.9 (2001{{ndash}}2002 and 2005{{ndash}}2012)==== In September 2001, Baker joined [[BBC London 94.9]] presenting a Saturday morning show from 8 to 11{{nbsp}}am. Just 6 months later, in March 2002, and with a new co-presenting team which included [[Amy Lamé]], Mark O'Donnell and [[David Kuo (financial adviser)|David Kuo]], he took over the breakfast show from 6 to 9{{nbsp}}am, with a new theme tune in the form of the [[Anthony Newley]] song ''[[The Candy Man]]''.
Although not drawing a large listenership, Baker won "[[Sony Radio Academy Awards|Sony Radio DJ of the year]]" for the show. However, the day after winning the award, he announced his intention to leave the show at the end of the month. The last show was on Friday 27 May 2005. On Monday 17 October 2005, after a sabbatical at home, Baker rejoined [[BBC London 94.9]] where he took over the weekday 3 to 5{{nbsp}}pm show from [[Jono Coleman]], who had moved to co-present the breakfast show with former actress [[JoAnne Good]].
His BBC London 94.9 shows tended to feature off-the-wall phone-ins and discussions with his on-air team, [[Amy Lamé|Amy]] and Baylen Leonard, often regarding music and entertainment nostalgia of the 1960s and 1970s. His interviews focused on off-beat trivia rather than the guests' latest or most famous work, and shows would be interspersed with relatively obscure rock tracks from bands such as [[Yes (band)|Yes]], [[Todd Rundgren]], [[Steely Dan]], [[Frank Zappa]] and [[Captain Beefheart]].
The programme was axed in November 2012 as part of a programme of cuts at the station. Although due to continue its run until the end of the year,<ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Plunkett |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/nov/01/danny-baker-bbc-show-axed |title=Danny Baker's afternoon show on BBC London to be axed in December |newspaper=The Guardian |date=1 November 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> Baker announced on air on the day of the announcement that that day's show would be his last, branding his BBC London employers as "pinheaded weasels" for the way in which they cancelled the programme.<ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Plunkett |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/nov/01/axed-danny-baker-bbc-rant |title=Axed Danny Baker delivers on-air rant at his BBC London bosses |newspaper=The Guardian |date= 1 November 2012 |accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref>
====All Day Breakfast Show/podcasts (2007)==== {{BLP unsourced section|date=December 2013}} On 15 March 2007 until September the same year, Baker hosted the ''[[All Day Breakfast Show]]'', a [[podcast]] to reach listeners beyond BBC London's FM radio reach. Regulars [[Amy Lamé]], Baylen Leonard and [[David Kuo (financial adviser)|David Kuo]] all contributed and the first show featured an appearance by comedian and actor [[Peter Kay]].
====Return to ''606'', Radio 2 and Saturday show (2008{{ndash}}present)==== Having announced on his BBC London radio show on 21 May 2008 that he would be returning to present [[BBC Radio 5 Live]]'s ''[[606 (radio show)|606]]'' football phone-in for a limited period that summer,<ref name="Guardian">{{cite news |first=Barry |last=Glendenning |url=http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/sport/2008/05/21/bakers_return_can_only_be_good.html |title=Baker's return can only be good |newspaper=The Guardian Blogs |date= 21 May 2008|accessdate=29 August 2011 |location=London |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080602030109/http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/sport/2008/05/21/bakers_return_can_only_be_good.html |archivedate=2 June 2008}}</ref> Baker hosted six shows during [[Euro 2008]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2008/05_may/19/baker.shtml |title=Danny Baker returns to 606 on Radio 5 Live |work=BBC Press Office |date=19 May 2008 |accessdate=29 August 2011}}</ref> He made a long-term return to ''606'' in September 2008, hosting a Tuesday night show for the duration of the 2008{{ndash}}09 football season.<ref>{{cite news |first=Oliver |last=Luft |title=Danny Baker returns to Radio 5 Live weekly phone-in 606 - yet again |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/jul/31/bbc.radio |newspaper=The Guardian |date=31 July 2008 |accessdate=8 August 2008 |location=London}}</ref> He also had a short stint with [[Zoë Ball]] on [[BBC Radio 2|Radio 2]] on Saturday mornings after [[Jonathan Ross]] had been [[The Russell Brand Show prank telephone calls row|suspended for three months by the BBC]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2008/11_november/13/radio2.shtml |title=Baker and Ball to co-present on Radio 2 |work=BBC Press Office |date=13 November 2008 |accessdate=29 August 2011}}</ref> At the end of the 2008{{ndash}}09 season, Baker's ''606'' Tuesday night show that he co-hosted with Issy Clarke shifted to an expanded Saturday morning slot, starting in September 2009 on BBC 5 Live. The show returned in September 2010 after the summer break with [[Lynsey Hipgrave]] replacing Clarke as co-host. The Saturday Morning show gained critical acclaim, winning the Gold [[Sony Radio Academy Awards|Sony Radio Award]] in the Speech Radio Personality of the Year award for the 2011, 2012 and 2014,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.radioacademyawards.org/winners/2012/people-awards/speech-radio-personality-of-the-year |title=The Winners 2012: Speech Radio Personality of the Year |work=Sony Radio Academy |date= |accessdate=15 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120519072028/http://www.radioacademyawards.org/winners/2012/people-awards/speech-radio-personality-of-the-year/ |archivedate=19 May 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/05/2014-radio-academy-awards-full-winners|title=2014 Radio Academy Awards: Full Winners |work=Radio Today}}</ref> and the Gold Award for the Entertainment Show of the Year in 2013.<ref>{{cite news |title=Baker takes top gong at Sony Awards|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/news/baker-takes-top-gong-at-sony-awards-29263409.html|newspaper=Belfast Telegraph |accessdate=13 May 2013}}</ref>
Since (July 2016) Louise Pepper has been his co-host in the studio. A popular feature of the Saturday Morning Programme is the Sausage Sandwich Game. A celebrity guest is asked two questions about their personal life that only they can answer. Two contestants representing local or national football teams, score 'goals' based on their ability to correctly guess the celebrity's answer. In the final question which gives the game its name, the contestants have to guess if the celebrity when offered a sausage sandwich would choose red sauce, brown sauce or no sauce at all. The second hour of the programme features a (different) celebrity interview followed by phone-in led banter.
==Other ventures== ===Football videos=== Baker has presented a number of popular football videos and DVDs including ''Own Goals and Gaffs'' (1992), ''Right Hammerings'', ''Whose Season Was It Anyway?'' (both 1993), ''Own Goals and Gaffs 2'' (1994), ''Fabulous World Of Freak Football'' (1995) and ''The Glorious Return Of Own Goals And Gaffs'' (2009).
''The Game'' (1990), a cult classic television show presented by Baker, following bottom-division East London Sunday League football teams, was released on DVD through [[Revelation Films]] on 24 May 2010.
===Books=== ====Football==== In 2009, he released a book co-written with [[Danny Kelly (journalist)|Danny Kelly]] entitled ''Classic Football Debates Settled Once and for All, Vol. 1''. Despite the title, the book itself makes clear that a sequel is not planned, though some extra material was written for the paperback edition, released to coincide with the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 World Cup]].
====Autobiography==== On 6 November 2012, Baker released an autobiography, ''Going to Sea in a Sieve''.<ref name=Autobiography /> which was first published by [[Weidenfeld & Nicolson]]. A second volume entitled ''Going Off Alarming'' was published on 25 September 2014.<ref>{{cite book|date=25 September 2014|first=Danny |last=Baker|isbn=978-0297870111|title= Going Off Alarming: The Autobiography: Vol 2|publisher= Weidenfeld & Nicolson}}</ref> A third volume entitled "Going on the Turn" was published on 5 October 2017.<ref>{{cite book|date=5 October 2017|first=Danny |last=Baker|isbn=978-0297870135|title= Going on the Turn|publisher= Weidenfeld & Nicolson}}</ref>
A sitcom called ''[[Cradle to Grave]]'' based on ''Going To Sea In A Sieve'' was released in September 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/news/story/000001533/danny_baker_cradle_to_grave_comedy_drama |title=Danny Baker gets 8-part BBC comedy drama |work=British Comedy Guide |date=2 July 2014}}</ref>
==Personal life== His interests range as widely as the [[United States]], [[progressive rock]], [[Steely Dan]], [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]], the [[Marx Brothers]] and [[P. G. Wodehouse]]. He has a large collection of [[Gramophone record|vinyl records]] and a collection of redundant [[laserdiscs]] that his family refer to as 'Baker's [[folly]]'.
Baker is a lifelong supporter of his local football club, [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/match_of_the_day/3625429.stm |title=FA Cup Final on Match of the Day |work=BBC News |date=14 April 2004 |accessdate=29 August 2011}}</ref>
Baker is married to Wendy (born 7 March 1955) They have three children: Bonnie, Sonny and Mancie. He lives in [[Blackheath, London|Blackheath]], south east London.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
On 1 November 2010, Baker announced that he had been diagnosed with [[cancer]] and would start [[chemotherapy]] instantly and [[Radiation therapy|radiotherapy]] in January.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-11668994 |title=BBC radio presenter Danny Baker diagnosed with cancer |work=BBC News |date=1 November 2010 |accessdate=29 August 2011}}</ref> On 14 June 2011 he announced that he had been given the all clear.<ref name="metro all clear">{{cite news |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/866255-danny-baker-ive-won-my-battle-against-cancer |title=Danny Baker: I've won my battle against cancer|date=14 June 2011 |newspaper=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] |accessdate=15 June 2011}}</ref>
Baker has been a lifelong [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] activist. In May 2017, Baker endorsed Labour Party leader [[Jeremy Corbyn]] in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 UK general election]].<ref name="mirror">{{cite news |last=Milne|first=Oliver|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/who-celebrities-voting-general-election-10546843|title=Who are celebrities voting for in 2017 General Election? The A-Z of famous names supporting Labour, the Tories, the Lib Dems and Greens|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Daily Mirror]]''|date=8 June 2017|accessdate=14 June 2017}}</ref>

revision.text: [[File:Æblegården_01.jpg|thumb|Æblegården]] The '''FDF Outdoor Center Sletten '''(Danish: '''"FDF Friluftscenter Sletten"''', short: "'''Sletten"''') is an outdoor center with a large camping area in [[Denmark]]. It belongs to the Danish youth organization [[Frivilligt Drenge- og Pige-Forbund|FDF]].{{Cite web|url=http://sletten.fdf.dk/|title=Sletten|website=sletten.fdf.dk|access-date=2016-06-17}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.dr.dk/levnu/fritid/vi-skal-i-skoven|title=Vi skal i skoven|website=DR|access-date=2016-06-17}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TE6PQwAACAAJ|title=Ny hovedbyning til FDF Friluftscenter Sletten i det midtjyske søhøjland: projektkonkurrence|date=2001-01-01|publisher=FDF|language=da}} ==Activities== The outdoor center is used for various recreational and educational activities. Each Easter and Autumn, FDF hosts annual training courses for young FDF leaders (aged 15–18 years) as well as the [[FDF National Camp]] every five years. ==Facilities== The area encompasses 225 acres of varied landscape.{{Cite web|url=http://www.visitdenmark.co.uk/en-gb/denmark/fdf-outdoor-centre-sletten-gdk714148|title=visit Denmark/contact info|website=VisitDenmark|access-date=2016-06-17}} The facilities of the center include: * Course center "Det ny Sletten" (English: "The new Sletten") * Camp building "Limbjerggård" * Base camp "Bøgebjerg" with [[hay barrack]]s * Sailing center and nature workshop "Æblegården" (English: "Apple Garden"), including an exhibition with the historical collection of FDF * Old barn with farm environment and workshop houses * Shelters and many camping areas ==See also== *[[Frivilligt Drenge- og Pige-Forbund]] (FDF) *[[Fimcap]] *[[FDF National Camp]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Fimcap}} {{European Fellowship}} [[Category:Skanderborg Municipality]] [[Category:Youth work]] [[Category:Fimcap]] [[Category:Youth organizations based in Denmark]] [[Category:Christian youth organizations]] [[Category:Christian summer camps]] {{Denmark-stub}}

10 [[Ku band]] | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = ''Intelsat VII'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat 605|Intelsat VI F-5]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat 702|Intelsat VII-F2]] }} '''Intelsat 701''' (also known as '''IS-701''' and '''Intelsat 7-F1''') is a [[geostationary]] [[communication]] [[satellite]] that was built by [[Space Systems/Loral]] (SSL). It is located in the orbital position of 29.5 degrees east longitude and it is currently in an [[inclined orbit]]. The same is owned by [[Intelsat]]. The satellite was based on the LS-1300 platform and its estimated useful life was 15 years. The satellite was successfully launched into space on October 22, 1993, at 06:46:00 UTC, using an [[Ariane 4]]4L vehicle from the [[Guiana Space Center]] in [[French Guiana]]. It had a launch mass of 3,642 kg. The Intelsat 701 is equipped with 26 transponders in [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] and 10 in [[Ku band]] to provide broadcasting, business-to-home services, [[telecommunications]], VSATnetworks. == External links == * [http://www.tbs-satellite.com/tse/online/sat_intelsat_701.html Intelsat 701] TBS satellite * [http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/intelsat-7.htm Intelsat 7] Gunter's Space Page * [http://www.satbeams.com/satellites?norad=22871 Intelsat 701] SatBeams {{Orbital launches in 1993}} {{Intelsat}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1993]] [[Category:Intelsat satellites]]

| launch_date = {{start-date|February 15, 2003, 06:44|timezone=yes}} UTC<ref name="launchlog">{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|work=Jonathan's Space Page|accessdate=May 23, 2017}}</ref> | launch_rocket = [[Ariane 4]]4L H10-3<ref name="gsp"/> | launch_site = [[Guiana Space Centre|Kourou]] [[ELA-2]]<ref name="gsp"/> | launch_contractor = [[Arianespace]]
| disposal_type = | deactivated =
| orbit_epoch = May 23, 2017<ref name="n2yo">{{cite web|url=http://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=27683|title=INTELSAT 907 |work=N2YO|accessdate=May 23, 2017}}</ref> | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|35,812.9|km|mi}}<ref name="n2yo"/> | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|35,775.1|km|mi}}<ref name="n2yo"/> | orbit_inclination = 0.0°<ref name="n2yo"/> | orbit_period = 1,436.1 minutes<ref name="n2yo"/> | orbit_semimajor = {{convert|42,164.0|km|mi}}<ref name="n2yo"/> | orbit_longitude = [[27th meridian east|27.5° west]]<ref name="satbeams"/><ref name="n2yo"/> | apsis = gee
| trans_band = 72 [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] and 23 {{Ku band}} | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = 36 [[Megahertz|MHz]] | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = [[Africa]], [[Australia]], [[Europe]], [[India]], [[Russia]] | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = 36-48 dBW ([[C band (IEEE)|C band]]) 53 dBW ({{Ku band}}) | trans_HPBW =
| programme = ''Intelsat 9'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat 906]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat 10-02]] (Intelsat 10) }}
'''Intelsat 907''' (or '''IS-907'''<ref name="satbeams"/>) is a [[communications satellite]] operated by [[Intelsat]].
== Launch == Intelsat 907 was launched by a [[Ariane 4]] rocket from [[Guiana Space Centre]], [[French Guiana]], at 06:44 UTC on February 15, 2003.<ref name="nssdc">{{cite web|url=https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=2003-007A|title=Intelsat 907 |work=NSSDC Master Catalog|accessdate=May 23, 2017}} {{PD-notice}}</ref>
== Capacity and coverage == The 4.7 tonne spacecraft will provide data-relay among installations in [[North America]], [[South America]], [[Western Europe]] and [[Africa]] through its array of [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] and [[Ku band]] [[transponder]]s after parking over 27.5 degrees west longitude. It replaces the aging [[Intelsat 605]].<ref name="nssdc"/>
== See also == * [[2003 in spaceflight]]
== External links == * {{url|www.intelsat.com|}}. [[Intelsat]]

[[File:"Kilishi".JPG|thumb|Kilishi]] [[File:Kilishi heaven.jpg|thumb|Kilishi drying in the sun ([[Nigeria]]).]] '''Kilishi''' is a version of [[jerky]] that originated in [[Hausaland]]. It is a dried form of [[suya]], made from deboned cow, sheep or goat meat. Each of the selected muscles is sliced into sheets of one metre or less for easy drying. The dried sheets of meat are then collected and kept for the next process.
A paste made from peanuts, called '''labu''', is diluted with enough water, spices, salt, ground onions, and sometimes sweeteners such as honey, to add sweetness. A more natural way to add sweetness is by adding date palm. The dried "sheets" of meat are then immersed one by one in the labu paste to coat them, before being left to dry for hours before roasting on a wire mesh.
Kilishi can be kept for months without much change to its taste.<ref>{{cite news|title=Special report: Kilishi, Nigeria’s meat of possibilities (video documentary) - Nigeria Today|url=http://www.nigeriatoday.ng/2016/04/special-report-kilishi-nigerias-meat-of-possibilities-video-documentary/|date=30 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Nigeria: Kano - Kilishi is Everything to the People|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201510280627.html|accessdate=7 July 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== {{portal|Food}} * [[List of dried foods]]
