{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox former country |conventional_long_name = Kingdom of Iceland |native_name = ''Konungsríkið Ísland'' {{is icon}}
''Kongeriget Island'' {{da icon}} |common_name = Iceland |continent = Europe |status = [[Personal union]] with [[Denmark]] |p1 = History of Iceland#Iceland under Norwegian and Danish kings (1262–1944){{!}}Iceland under Danish rule |flag_p1 = Flag of Denmark.svg |s1 = Iceland |flag_s1 = Flag of Iceland.svg |image_flag = Light Blue Flag of Iceland.svg |image_coat = Kingdom of Iceland Coat of Arms.svg |national_motto = |national_anthem = ''[[Lofsöngur]]''
[[File:Lofsöngur.ogg]]
({{Lang-en|"Song of Praise")}} |image_map = Kingdom of Iceland (1942).svg |image_map_caption = The Kingdom of Iceland in 1942 |capital = [[Reykjavík]] |common_languages = [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]], [[Danish language|Danish]] |religion = [[Church of Iceland]] |government_type = [[Constitutional monarchy]] |title_leader = [[Monarchy of Iceland|King]] |leader1 = [[Christian X of Denmark|Kristján X]] |year_leader1 = 1918–1944 |title_representative = [[Regent]] |representative1 = [[Sveinn Björnsson]] |year_representative1 = 1941–1944 |title_deputy = [[Prime Minister of Iceland|Prime Minister]] |deputy1 = [[Jón Magnússon (politician)|Jón Magnússon]] (first) |year_deputy1 = 1918–1920 |deputy2 = [[Björn Þórðarson]] (last) |year_deputy2 = 1942–1944 |legislature = [[Althing]] |era = [[Interwar period]] / [[World War II|WWII]] |event_start = [[Danish–Icelandic Act of Union|Act of Union]] |date_start = 1 December |year_start = 1918 |event1 = [[Occupation of Denmark|Fall of Denmark]] |date_event1 = 9 April 1940 |event2 = [[Invasion of Iceland|Operation Fork]] |date_event2 = 10 May 1940 |event3 = [[Icelandic constitutional referendum, 1944|National referendum]] |date_event3 = 20 May 1944 |event_end = [[Founding of the Republic of Iceland|Republic proclaimed]] |date_end = 17 June |year_end = 1944 |stat_year1 = 1944 |stat_area1 = 103125 |stat_pop1 = 125967 |ref_pop1 = [http://www.statice.is/?PageID=1170&src=/temp_en/Dialog/varval.asp?ma=MAN00000%26ti=Population+-+key+figures+1703-2011++++++%26path=../Database/mannfjoldi/Yfirlit/%26lang=1%26units=Number Statistics of Iceland]. Retrieved on 18 March 2014. |currency = [[Icelandic króna|Króna]] }} {{History of Iceland}} The '''Kingdom of Iceland''' ({{lang-is|Konungsríkið Ísland}}; {{lang-da|Kongeriget Island}}) was a [[constitutional monarchy]], a sovereign and independent country that was established by the [[Danish–Icelandic Act of Union|Act of Union]] with [[Denmark]] signed on 1 December 1918.{{cite book|last=Halfdanarson|first=Gudmundur Halfdanarson|title=The A to Z of Iceland|year=2010|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=0810872080|pages=23–25|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kDrZWBMGJ8wC&pg=PR23&dq=Monarchy+of+Iceland+1918#v=onepage&q=Monarchy%20of%20Iceland%201918&f=false}} It lasted until 17 June 1944 when a [[Icelandic constitutional referendum, 1944|national referendum established the Republic of Iceland]] in its place.{{cite book|last=Van Cleaf|first=Kristin Van Cleaf|title=Iceland|year=2007|publisher=ABDO|isbn=1599287846|pages=7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zbhQoMd2jhcC&pg=PA7&dq=Monarchy+of+Iceland+1918#v=onepage&q=Monarchy%20of%20Iceland%201918&f=false}} ==Origins of Danish rule== {{See also|History of Iceland}} Because of the [[Kalmar Union]], Iceland had been under the control of the [[Monarchy of Denmark|Crown of Denmark]] since 1380,{{cite book |last=Nordstrom |first=Byron |year=2000 |title=Scandinavia since 1500 |publisher=[[University of Minnesota]] Press |page=147 |isbn=0-8166-2098-9}} although formally it had been a [[List of possessions of Norway|Norwegian possession]] until 1814.{{cite book |last=Dörr |first=Oliver |title=Kompendium völkerrechtlicher Rechtsprechung |year=2004 |publisher=Mohr Siebeck |isbn=3-16-148311-1|language=German |page=103}} In 1874, one thousand years after the first [[Settlement of Iceland|acknowledged settlement]], Denmark granted Iceland [[home rule]]. The constitution, written the same year, was revised in 1903 and the extent of Iceland's home rule increased in 1904.{{Cite web |url=https://europa.eu/youth/is/article/61/4215_en |title=A short history of Alþingi - the oldest parliament in the world |website=European Youth Portal |publisher=European Union |language=en |access-date=29 November 2018 }} A [[Minister for Iceland|minister for Icelandic affairs]], residing in [[Reykjavík]], was made responsible to the ''[[Althing]]'', the Icelandic parliament. ==Establishment of the kingdom== {{See also|Danish–Icelandic Act of Union}} [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-00102A, König Christian X. von Dänemark.jpg|mni|thumb|[[Christian X of Denmark]]]] On 1 December 1918, the [[Danish–Icelandic Act of Union|Act of Union]], an agreement with Denmark, recognized Iceland as a fully [[sovereign state]], an independent country in [[personal union]] with Denmark through a common [[Monarchy of Iceland|monarch]]. The Kingdom of Iceland established its [[Flag of Iceland|own flag]] and [[Coat of arms of Iceland|coat of arms]] and asked that Denmark represent its foreign affairs and defence interests on its behalf while retaining full control over its foreign affairs and defence. Iceland opened its first Embassy in 1920. The Act would be reviewed in 1940 and could be revoked three years later if agreement to continue it could not be reached.{{cite book |title=The History of Iceland |first=Gunnar |last=Karlsson |publisher=University of Minnesota Press |isbn=9780816635894 |pages=283–284 |date=15 April 2000 }} ==World War II, British occupation and the establishment of the republic== {{Main article|Iceland during World War II|Invasion of Iceland|Occupation of Iceland|Ástandið|Founding of the Republic of Iceland}} The German [[Denmark in World War II|occupation of Denmark]] on 9 April 1940 severed communications between Iceland and Denmark. As a result, on 10 April, the Althing passed two [[Resolution (law)|resolution]]s investing the Icelandic cabinet with the power of [[head of state]] and declaring that Iceland would accept full responsibility for both [[foreign policy]] and coastal surveillance. A year later, on 15 May 1941 the Althing adopted a law creating the position of [[regent]] for [[Sveinn Björnsson]] in order to represent the monarchy. During the first year of [[World War II]], Iceland strictly enforced a position of [[Neutrality (international relations)|neutrality]] and took action against both [[British Armed Forces|British]] and [[Wehrmacht|German forces]] that violated it. On 10 May 1940, [[Invasion of Iceland|Operation ''Fork'']] was launched by the United Kingdom when military forces sailed into Reykjavík harbour and began an invasion of Iceland. The government of Iceland issued a protest against what it called a "flagrant violation" of Icelandic neutrality. On the day of the invasion, Prime Minister [[Hermann Jónasson]] read a radio announcement instructing Icelanders to treat the British troops as guests. The [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] occupation of Iceland lasted until 1941 when the Government of Iceland asked the United States to take over its defence. The defence of Iceland was the United States' first participation in World War II. At its peak, Britain had approximately 25,000 troops stationed in Iceland, all but eliminating unemployment in Reykjavík and other strategically important places. In July 1941, the ''Althingi'' adopted the American–Icelandic defence agreement, passing responsibility for Iceland's defence to the [[United States]]. As many as 40,000 American soldiers were then stationed on the island, outnumbering the native population of adult men. (Iceland's total native population during the war was approximately 120,000.) Following a [[Icelandic constitutional referendum, 1944|constitutional referendum in May 1944]], Iceland formally became a [[Founding of the Republic of Iceland|republic]] on 17 June 1944. Many Danes felt offended at its timing, as Denmark was still occupied by [[Nazi Germany|Germany]].{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} The king in [[Copenhagen]], [[Christian X of Denmark|Christian X]], nonetheless sent a message of congratulations to the Icelandic people.{{cite journal|last1=Hardarson|first1=Solrun B. Jensdottir|title=The 'Republic of Iceland' 1940–44: Anglo-American Attitudes and Influences|journal=Journal of Contemporary History|date=October 1974|volume=9|issue=4|pages=27–56|jstor=260290}} ==Flags== {{See also|Flag of Iceland|List of flags of Iceland}}
File:Light Blue Flag of Iceland.svg|Flag of Iceland (1915–1944)[https://flagspot.net/flags/is-hist.html#1915 Iceland – Flag History] at ''[[Flags of the World]]''. Retrieved on 18 March 2014. File:State flag of Iceland (1918–1944).svg|State Flag of Iceland (1915–1944) File:Royal Standard of Iceland (1921-1944).svg|Royal Standard (1921–1944)[https://flagspot.net/flags/is-royal.html#regt Iceland – Royal Standard] at ''[[Flags of the World]]''. Retrieved on 18 March 2014. File:Standard of the Regent of Iceland (1941–1944).svg|Standard of the Regent (1941–1944)
==See also== {{Portal|Iceland}} * [[Nobility in Iceland]] * [[Icelandic independence movement]] * [[Danish realm]] * [[Constitution of Denmark]] * [[Greenlandic independence]] * [[Faroese independence]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== * [http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/281235/Iceland/10100/Home-rule-and-sovereignty-1904-44 "Iceland, Home Rule and Sovereignty (1904–44)"] at ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]''. revision.text:
[[File:P1050576 Louvre Oblélisque de Manishtusu rwk.JPG|thumb|Manishtusu obelisk - Louvre Museum]] [[File:P1050578 Louvre Obélisque de Manishtusu détail rwk.JPG|thumb|left|Manishtusu obelisk (detail) - Louvre museum]] The '''Manishtushu Obelisk''' is a [[diorite]], four-sided [[stele]]. The stele is [[obelisk]]-shaped, as well as it narrows upward to its (damaged) top, in a [[pyramid]]al-form. The obelisk was made by [[Manishtushu]], son of [[Sargon of Akkad|Sargon the Great]], of the [[Akkadian Empire]], who ruled circa 2270-2255 BC.
As a spoil of war, the stele was taken to [[Susa]] by the [[Elam]]ite king [[Shutruk-Nakhunte]] in the 12th century BC.
==Description and purpose== The Manishtusu Obelisk is 1.4 m tall, and 0.6 m wide<ref>Manishtusu Obelisk, [[Louvre|Louvre Museum]]</ref> on its four sides. It is made of deep black diorite, and incised in [[Akkadian language]] [[cuneiform]] in horizontal rows on all sides. The cuneiform is written within 1519 boxes, as lined [[register (sculpture)|register]]s. The diorite is from [[Oman]], located to the south, and on [[clay tablet]]s, Manishtusu recorded: ''"From mountains beyond the 'lower sea' ([[Persian Gulf]]), he took black stones; he loaded [them] on boats and docked [them] on the quay at [[Akkad (city)|Akkad]]. He fashioned his statue [and] dedicated [it] to [[Enlil]].''<ref>Manishtusu Obelisk, Louvre</ref>
The obelisk text is a [[law|legal record]] that records the distribution of four parcels of land, in large estates, and its allotment to his officers, for his control of [[Kish (Sumer)|Kish]].<ref>Manishtusu Obelisk, Louvre</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.louvre.fr/en/oeuvre-notices/obelisk Manishtusu Obelisk, Near Eastern Antiquities, Louvre]
[[Category:23rd-century BC works]] [[Category:Ancient Near East steles]] [[Category:Ancient obelisks]] [[Category:Babylonia]] [[Category:Akkadian inscriptions]]

{{refimprove|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox military rank | name = Marshal | native_name = Mareşal | image = Turkey-army-OF-10.svg | image_size = 120px | caption = ''Mareşal'' shoulder insignia. | image2 = | image_size2 = 100px | caption2 = | country = {{flag|Turkey}} | service branch = [[Turkish Armed Forces]] | abbreviation = | rank = Officer | NATO rank = [[Ranks and insignia of NATO armies officers|OF-10]] | Non-NATO rank = | formation = 1921 | abolished = | higher rank = None | lower rank = [[General officer|Orgeneral]]
[[Admiral|Oramiral]] | equivalents = }} '''Mareşal''/''Büyükamiral''' ([[Marshal]]) is the highest rank in the [[Army]] of [[Turkey]], the [[Turkish Armed Forces]]. It is the equivalent of a [[Field Marshal]] in other countries. The rank of ''Mareşal''/''Büyükamiral'' can trace its origins to the [[Ottoman Empire]]{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}} and to the military of [[Persia]], where the rank was bestowed upon senior commanders upon order of the ruling [[Sultan]]. The word ''mariscalcus'' in Latin, had parts from the old-German words meaning horse and servant. The rank of ''Mareşal''/''Büyükamiral'' can only be bestowed by the [[Grand National Assembly of Turkey|National Assembly]], and only given to a [[General]]/[[Admiral]] who leads an army, navy and/or air force with an extraordinary success in battle gaining a victory over the enemy. The corresponding rank in the Turkish [[Navy]] is known as ''[[Büyükamiral]]''. '''Marshals of Turkey''': Only two persons were bestowed the rank ''Mareşal'' to date: [[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk]] (on 21 September 1921) and [[Chief of staff (military)|chief of staff]] [[Fevzi Çakmak]] (on 31 August 1922), both for their successes in the [[Turkish War of Independence]]. ==References== [http://www.mevzuat.adalet.gov.tr/html/416.html Turkish Armed Forces Employee Law[Turkish]] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110145103/http://www.mevzuat.adalet.gov.tr/html/416.html |date=10 November 2012 }} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}} {{Highest Military Ranks}} {{Star officer ranks}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Maresal (Turkey)}} [[Category:Field marshals of Turkey| ]] [[Category:Military ranks of Turkey]] [[Category:Turkish words and phrases]] {{Turkey-stub}} {{mil-rank-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox official post |post = Prime Minister |body = the
Republic of Angola |insignia = Emblem of Angola.svg |insigniasize = 125px |insigniacaption = [[Emblem of Angola]] |image = |imagesize = 120px |imagecaption = |style = |residence = |appointer = [[President of Angola|President of the Republic of Angola]] |appointer_qualified = |precursor = |formation = 14 November 1975 |first = [[Lopo do Nascimento]] |last = [[Paulo Kassoma]] |abolished = 4 February 2010 |succession = [[Vice President of Angola]] |salary = }} {{Politics of Angola}} According to the 1992 constitution, the '''Prime Minister of Angola''' was a high government official in [[Angola]], but with limited powers as head of government. Along with the rest of the Council of Ministers, the Prime Minister was appointed by the [[President of Angola|President]]. The position was originally created when Angola achieved independence from [[Portugal]] on 11 November 1975, but was abolished in 1978 when President [[Agostinho Neto]] consolidated his power. There was no Prime Minister until 1991, when President [[José Eduardo dos Santos]] reinstated the position following a peace agreement with the opposition party. The post was also vacant between 1999 and 2002. The post was again abolished due to the 2010 [[Constitution of Angola]], which integrates the functions of the prime minister into the office of the president, who is not subjected to the confidence of the parliamentary majority, contrarily to the prime minister. ==List of Prime Ministers of Angola== {{main|List of heads of government of Angola}} ==See also== *[[List of current Angolan ministers]] {{Angola topics}} {{Prime Minister}} [[Category:Government of Angola]] [[Category:Lists of prime ministers|Angola, Prime Minister]] [[Category:Angola politics-related lists|Prime Minister]] {{Angola-gov-stub}}

{{Infobox Former Country |native_name = |conventional_long_name = Principality of Trinidad
Principauté de Trinidad {{fr icon}}
Principado de Trinidad {{pt icon}} |common_name = Trinidad |status = [[List of historical unrecognized countries|Unrecognized state]] |continent = South America |region = South Atlantic |era = |event_start = |date_start = |year_start = 1893 |event_end = |date_end = |year_end = 1895 |p1 = History of Brazil (1889–1930) |flag_p1 = Flag of Brazil (1889-1960).svg |p2 = United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland |flag_p2 = Flag of the United Kingdom.svg |s1 = History of Brazil (1889–1930) |flag_s1 = Flag of Brazil (1889-1960).svg |image_flag = Flag of the Principality of Trinidad.svg |image_coat = Coat of arms of the Principality of Trinidad.svg |symbol_type = |image_map = TrindadeMapCruiseOfTheAlerte.jpg |image_map_caption = Map of Trinidad from the book, ''The Cruise of the Alerte'' |national_motto = |national_anthem = |capital = |common_languages = [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] |government_type = Self-proclaimed monarchy |title_leader = Prince |leader1 = James Harden-Hickey |year_leader1 = 1893-1895 |stat_year1 = |stat_pop1 = |currency = }} The '''Principality of Trinidad''' was a short-lived unrecognized state declared in 1893"To Be Prince of Trinidad: He Is Baron Harden-Hickey," ''New York Tribune'', Nov 5, 1893, p 1 when the American [[James Harden-Hickey]] claimed the uninhabited [[Trindade Island]] in the South Atlantic. He declared himself James I, Prince of Trinidad,Bryk, William, [http://www.nypress.com/15/50/news&columns/oldsmoke.cfm News & Columns] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060430105931/http://www.nypress.com/15/50/news%26columns/oldsmoke.cfm |date=2006-04-30 }}, ''[[New York Press]]'', v 15 no 50 (Dec 10, 2002)"Principality of Trinidad: John H. Flagler's Son-in-Law Is Its Sovereign, Self-Proclaimed as James I," ''New York Times'', June 10, 1894, p 23 and intended for the islands to become a [[military dictatorship]] under his leadership. Britain and Brazil later argued over the territory, and it is now a part of the state of [[Espírito Santo]] in southeastern Brazil."Mr. Hickey's Trinidad Invaded: Great Britain's Warship Barracouta Takes Possession of the Land While the Prince Is in California," ''New York Times'', Jun 18, 1895, p 3"Trinidad's Prince Awake: An Appeal to Washington Against Brazil and Great Britain," ''New York Times'', Aug 1, 1895, p 1"Grand Chancellor of Trinidad: Significant Phases in the Ascent of Male Comte de la Boissiere to His Elevated Diplomatic Post," ''New York Times'', Aug 2, 1895, p 9"Trinidad's Case in Washington: Courteously, the Chancellor Would Permit Britain's Cable Station and Use It, but There Is Graver Trouble," ''New York Times'', Aug 7, 1895, p 1"Trinidad's Diplomat in Action: M. de la Boissiere Asks that His Sovereign's Land Be Recognized as a Neutral Principality," ''New York Times'', Aug 9, 1895, p 5"Trinidad's Prince at Work: Grand Chancellor de la Boissiere Tells How the War Between Great Britain and Brazil Will Be Averted," ''New York Times'', Jan 24, 1896, p 9[http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/br-trin.html Flags of the World - Trindade and Martins Vaz Islands (Brazil)] ==Name== The original name of the island, ''Trindade'', is Portuguese for "[[trinity]]"; ''Trinidad'' is the Spanish [[cognate]]. It is unclear why Harden-Hickley chose to translate the name from Portuguese into Spanish, and not English. Earlier, nearby [[Ascension Island]] had been renamed from its original Portuguese name ''Ascensão'' when it passed into British hands. == History == While traveling to [[Tibet]] before his marriage, Harden-Hickey noticed the tiny island of Trindade in the South Atlantic Ocean, which had never been claimed by any country and was, legally, ''[[terra nullius]]''. In 1893, wanting an independent state where he could serve as its ruler, he claimed the island and proclaimed himself James I, the Prince of Trinidad. He designed postage stamps, a national flag and [[coat of arms]], and established a [[chivalric order]], the Cross of Trinidad. He bought a [[schooner]] to transport colonists, appointed M. Le Comte De la Boissiere as Secretary of State, and opened a consular office at 217 West 36th Street in [[New York City]]. He issued [[government bond]]s to finance the construction of infrastructure on the island. In July 1895, the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|British]] tried to take possession of the island, basing their claim on the 1700 visit by English astronomer [[Edmund Halley]]. The British planned to use the island as a telegraph cable station. However, Brazilian diplomatic efforts, along with Portuguese support,{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} pressed a successful claim to Brazilian sovereignty, based on the island's discovery in 1502 by Portuguese navigators. To demonstrate sovereignty over the island, the state of Espírito Santo, which took the island, built a landmark on January 24, 1897. ===Today=== Today, Brazil marks its presence with a permanent [[Brazilian Navy]] base on the main island. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Trinidad, Principality Of}} [[Category:Former unrecognized countries]] [[Category:Former principalities]] [[Category:Former monarchies of South America]] [[Category:Island countries]] [[Category:Micronations]] [[Category:States and territories established in 1893]] [[Category:1893 establishments in South America]] [[Category:1895 disestablishments]] [[Category:Modern history of Brazil]] [[Category:Espírito Santo]] {{Brazil-geo-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = Verax | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = Online poster | director = Jeff Floro, Edwin Lee, Shawn Tse, Marcus Tsui | producer = Jeff Floro, Edwin Lee, Shawn Tse, Marcus Tsui | writer = Edwin Lee, Marcus Tsui | starring = Andrew Cromeek, Thomas Easterling, Gabe Ostley, Robert Hinson, Edwin Chin, Justin Lau, Cindy Wong, Simon Zeng Hao, Shi Yi Ng, Guo Aibing | music = Gareth Coker, Thomas Vo | cinematography = Jeff Floro, Shawn Tse | editing = Edwin Lee | studio = J.Shot Videos, Fallout Media, Immortal Peach | distributor = [[YouTube]] | released = {{Film date|2013|06|25}} | runtime = 5.5 minutes | country = Hong Kong | language = English, Cantonese, Mandarin | budget = HKD $5000 }} '''''Verax''''' is a five-minute 2013 short film about the [[Edward Snowden]] leaking event in Hong Kong. Produced by amateur filmmakers in Hong Kong, it was posted to YouTube in June 2013.<ref name=AFPSnowdenfilm>[http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1272335/hong-kong-amateur-filmmakers-produce-worlds-first-edward-snowden-film "Hong Kong amateur filmmakers produce world's first Edward Snowden film"]. ''South China Morning Post'' (Hong Kong). Agence France-Presse. 30 June 2013. Retrieved 30 June 2013.</ref> The name of the film originates from Snowden's codename for himself,<ref name=NapolitanoLCL>Napolitano, Dean (28 June 2013).[https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2013/06/28/lights-camera-leaks-watch-edward-snowden-the-movie/ "Lights, Camera, Leaks! Watch Edward Snowden: The Movie"]. ''The Wall Street Journal'' blog. Retrieved 30 June 2013.</ref> which means "truth teller" in [[Latin]].<ref name=JinCCTV>Jin, Jiabao. "[http://english.cntv.cn/program/cultureexpress/20130708/105188.shtml Hong Kong film buffs create first Snowden movie]." ([https://archive.is/20130803234820/http://english.cntv.cn/program/cultureexpress/20130708/105188.shtml Archive]) ''[[China Central Television]]''. 8 July 2013. Retrieved on 11 July 2013.</ref> It was produced by the group J.Shot Videos.<ref name=FlorCruz>FlorCruz, Michelle. "[http://www.ibtimes.com/watch-verax-edward-snowden-movie-hong-kong-filmmakers-video-1323911 Watch 'Verax,' The Edward Snowden Movie By Hong Kong Filmmakers [VIDEO]]." ''[[International Business Times]]''. 26 June 2013. Retrieved on 1 July 2013.</ref> According to the producers, this was the first film ever produced about Snowden.<ref name=VoiceofRussia>"[http://english.ruvr.ru/news/2013_06_30/Hong-Kong-filmmakers-publish-online-first-movie-about-Edward-Snowden-5065/ Hong Kong filmmakers publish online first movie about Edward Snowden]." ''[[Voice of Russia]]''. 30 June 2013. 1 July 2013.</ref>
==Plot== The film has four parts. The first depicts [[Central Intelligence Agency]] employees discussing the Snowden case.<ref name=VoiceofRussia/> The second involves a newspaper journalist corresponding with Snowden.<ref name=VoiceofRussia/> The third involves Hong Kong police officers and Chinese [[Ministry of State Security (China)|Ministry of State Security]] employees discussing and trying to find [[Edward Snowden]].<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/><ref name=VoiceofRussia/><!--Napolitano identifies them as Ministry of State Security--> The fourth involves the characters waiting for Snowden to appear,<ref name=VoiceofRussia/> and when Snowden reveals himself in the media.<ref name=FraterSnowdeliv>Frater, Patrick. "[https://variety.com/2013/digital/news/snowden-film-team-delivers-digital-snapshot-1200503490/ Snowden YouTube Film Delivers Digital Snapshot]" ({{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/6WwGTN3Jy?url=http://variety.com/2013/digital/news/snowden-film-team-delivers-digital-snapshot-1200503490/ |date=11 March 2015 }}). ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''. 1 July 2013. Retrieved on 2 July 2013.</ref> The end of the film includes extracts of Snowden's interview with ''[[The Guardian]]''. The final captions state that Snowden departed Hong Kong on 23 June.<ref name=VoiceofRussia/> The film features [[The Mira]], the Hong Kong hotel where Snowden stayed. A [[Rubik's cube]], an item which, according to the ''[[Agence France-Presse]]'', "Snowden reportedly used to identify himself to a ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' journalist," is featured in the film.<ref name=AFPSnowdenfilm/> Marcus Tsui, one of the project's filmmakers, described the film as a "snapshot in time".<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/>
Andreas Wiseman of ''[[Screen Daily]]'' wrote that the plot uses "a large degree of creative licence<!--British spelling-->".<ref>Wiseman, Andreas. "[http://www.screendaily.com/news/us-heavyweights-circle-snowden-rights/5060804.article?blocktitle=LATEST-FILM-NEWS&contentID=40562 US heavyweights circle Edward Snowden film rights]." ''[[Screen Daily]]''. 25 September 2013. Retrieved on 17 October 2013. "But both Doering and Hollywood were beaten to a film about Snowden by Verax, a five-minute video made for about $550, which has drawn more than 270,000 views on YouTube. The short, produced by the group J.Shot Videos, documents Snowden's three-week stay in the Far East and includes a large degree of creative licence while depicting imagined meetings at the Pentagon,{{sic}} and between Chinese and Hong Kong security services. Verax stars Andrew Cromeek, an American school teacher in Hong Kong who bears an uncanny resemblance to Snowden." - NOTE: The summary mistakes the CIA meeting for being a meeting at the Pentagon.</ref><!--Original URL: http://www.screendaily.com/news/us-players-circle-snowden-rights/5060804.article -->
==Conception and motives== The film was created by expatriates from Australia, Canada, Ireland, and the United States.<ref name=AFPSnowdenfilm/> The producers of the film were Jeff Floro, Edwin Lee{{#tag:ref|{{zh|c=李健恩|p=Lǐ Jiànēn}}|group=note}}, Shawn Tse{{#tag:ref|{{zh|first=t|t=謝兆龍|s=谢兆龙|p=Xiè Zhàolóng}}|group=note}}, and Marcus Tsui{{#tag:ref|{{zh|first=t|t=崔正傑|s=崔正杰|p=Cuī Zhèngjié|labels=no}}|group=note}}.<ref name=FraterSnowdeliv/> Lee, an Irish citizen,<ref name=CNNLai>Lai, Alexis. "[http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/01/world/asia/first-movie-about-edward-snowden/index.html?nbd=5_things Amateurs beat Hollywood to make first Edward Snowden movie]." ''[[CNN]]''. Monday 1 July 2013. Retrieved on 2 July 2013.</ref> and the sole professional filmmaker involved, served as the editor and cinematographer.<ref name=AFPSnowdenfilm/> Lee had served as a journalist in the multimedia and television sectors and had worked for the ''[[South China Morning Post]]'' and [[ATV Home]].<ref name=FraterSnowdeliv/> On 11 July 2013, two days after Snowden revealed his identity, Edwin Lee had contacted his friends on the possibility of making a film.<ref name=CNNLai/> Lee and Tsui created the film's script,<ref name=FraterSnowdeliv/> and did so one day before shooting. The actors had no time to rehearse their lines.<ref name=CNNLai/>
According to the producers, the film was intended to be an homage to Hong Kong.<ref name=CNNLai/> Lee said "We were so intrigued as to why Snowden came to Hong Kong. All of us love Hong Kong to death; we all call Hong Kong home."<ref name=CNNLai/> The filmmakers, on the group YouTube page, stated "While nearly every media outlet wanted to get their hands on him, we decided to produce a short fiction video to depict his experience in HK, and how it would have affected certain parties. Namely, the CIA contingent based in HK who would be tasked to find Snowden. The Hong Kong police who would be stuck in between the U.S. and China, and the journalists who want to get the scoop."<ref name=FlorCruz/> Lee said that the film was created "to catch onto the interest on Snowden and the attention on Hong Kong."<ref name=AFPSnowdenfilm/> According to Tse, a then 28-year-old native of [[Toronto]], Ontario and a graduate of the [[York University]] film studies programme who worked as a teacher in Hong Kong,<ref name=DeMaraBoost>DeMara, Bruce. "[https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/movies/2013/07/16/edward_snowden_movie_gives_toronto_expat_filmmaker_a_boost.html Edward Snowden ‘movie’ gives Toronto ex-pat filmmaker a boost]." ''[[Toronto Star]]''. Tuesday 16 July 2013. Retrieved on 21 July 2013.</ref> "We tried to give Hong Kong the limelight we think it deserves."<ref name=CNNLai/> Tse said that the group had initially considered an outright comedy, a spoof, or a thriller in the style of [[Jason Bourne]]; ultimately they opted for a depiction of the events that may have unfolded.<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/> Lee said that the Bourne film series and the works of director [[Michael Mann (director)|Michael Mann]] had inspired him.<ref name=CNNLai/>
In regards to Snowden's presence, the filmmakers stated that while Snowden is "a central character, he is not the most prominent. It is more about the maelstrom of events surrounding him."<ref name=FlorCruz/> This was because they knew too little about Snowden himself to give him a more prominent role in the story.<ref name=FlorCruz/> Lee said that the film focuses more on the "vignettes" than on Snowden and that Snowden serves as a catalyst for events that affect the other characters.<ref name=CNNLai/> Snowden himself has no live dialogue in the film. Lee said that half of the film's focus was on Hong Kong, and half was on Snowden.<ref name=CNNLai/><!--The film uses an excerpt from his videotaped speech but CNN says "Curiously Snowden has no dialogue in the film."-->
The four filmmakers stated that they had no political motives.<ref name=KeeganFilm/> Shawn Tse said that "We knew right from the get-go that this film was going to be as neutral as possible and in a way try not to infringe upon basically what we thought Snowden was trying to do, because really we had no idea."<ref>"[http://hereandnow.wbur.org/2013/08/20/whistleblowers-big-screen Whistleblowers’ Stories Head To The Big Screen]." ([https://archive.is/20130827061953/http://hereandnow.wbur.org/2013/08/20/whistleblowers-big-screen Archive]) ''[[WBUR]]''. Tuesday 20 August 2013. Retrieved on 27 August 2013.</ref> Lee described the film as a "snapshot in time" and said that "When Snowden popped up in Hong Kong he got so much attention that it really got people talking. We wanted to give an alternative view on the situation, beyond the media chase for where he was and what he knew."<ref name=FraterSnowdeliv/> Cassandra Chan, who served as the associate producer, said "The US government has abused the internet, so our response is to use the power of the internet, for hopefully good reasons."<ref name=FraterSnowdeliv/>
Dean Napolitano of ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' wrote that the film "makes subtle observations about Hong Kong's sometimes tense relationship with [[mainland China]] and the "[[one country, two systems]]" policy – underscored in a scene where a security official from [[Government of the People's Republic of China|China's central government]] barks orders to Hong Kong police officers."<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/> During the aforementioned scene, the official from the Mainland speaks [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]] while the Hong Kong officials speak [[Cantonese]].<ref name=CNNLai/> According to Napolitano, the film implies that the Chinese authorities have the real power in Hong Kong.<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/> Lee stated that the scene was "vehicle to represent (Hong Kong's) relationship with China" and, as paraphrased by Alexis Lai of ''[[CNN]]'', "the murkiness of Beijing's role in the Snowden affair."<ref name=CNNLai/> In regards to the scene, Lee said "To say China wasn't pulling any strings at all would be naïve ... Even though it gives us autonomy, it's always Beijing that calls the shots."<ref name=CNNLai/> Officially officials from the Mainland government said that they did not influence the decisions of the Hong Kong authorities.<ref name=CNNLai/>
By 1 July 2013 Edwin Lee said that because Snowden left Hong Kong, there are no plans to write a sequel.<ref name=CNNLai/> By 29 July 2013, the filmmakers had plans to show their film at film festivals, and considered making a sequel.<ref name=IpStephanieProud/>
==Filming and monetary costs== The film was shot in three,<ref name=KeeganFilm>Keegan, Rebecca (28 June 2013). [http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-edward-snowden-movie-youtube-20130628,0,4829594.story "Edward Snowden insta-movie hits YouTube"]. ''Los Angeles Times''. Retrieved 30 June 2013.</ref> or four days.<ref>Atkinson, Katie. "[http://popwatch.ew.com/2013/06/30/edward-snowden-movie-hong-kong/ An Edward Snowden movie already? Sort of! – VIDEO]." ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''. 30 June 2013. Retrieved on 1 July 2013.</ref> At the time of shooting, Snowden was hiding within Hong Kong.<ref name=KeeganFilm/> By the end of the film production, Snowden had fled to Russia.<ref name=AFPSnowdenfilm/> Edwin Lee said that this quickened the editing process so the film could be released sooner, but that it did not shorten the project itself. ''Agence France-Presse'' stated that the film "stayed true to the actual locations in Hong Kong where Snowden was reportedly seen."<ref name=AFPSnowdenfilm/> Some scenes were shot at [[The Mira Hotel]].<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/> Several office interiors were used for other scenes. A lingerie company let the filmmakers use their offices.<ref name=FraterSnowdeliv/>
Edwin Lee, one of the filmmakers said that the filming style was "a lot of adrenaline... it was all very guerilla filmmaking style."<ref name=AFPSnowdenfilm/> He also stated that "It was foot-on-the-gas filmmaking."<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/> Lee described the filming style as a "[[docu-drama]] recreation."<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/> Napolitano said that "In some ways it resembles a modern Hong Kong crime drama, with its technical dialogue in sterile conference rooms, time-lapse photography, and sweeping aerial shots of the city's famous skyline."<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/> Jonathan DeHart of ''[[The Diplomat]]'' stated that the usage of time-lapse-style footage of grey clouds, the Hong Kong panoramas, and the "shaky cam" style are features of "spy" genre films.<ref name=DeHartDiplomat>DeHart, Jonathan. "[http://thediplomat.com/asia-life/2013/07/edward-snowden-the-real-jason-bourne/ Edward Snowden: The Real Jason Bourne?]" ''[[The Diplomat]]''. 2 July 2013. Retrieved on 10 July 2013.</ref> The film used original photography with the exception of two stock photography shots purchased from [[Pond5]].<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/>
As of 28 June 2013 the filmmakers had not yet determined the total cost of the film. Their estimate of the budget was about $5,000 [[Hong Kong dollars]] ($641 US dollars).<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/> The AFP said that this budget was "shoestring".<ref name=AFPSnowdenfilm/> Patrick Frater of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' stated on 1 June 2013 that the total cost was $4,200 HKD ($550 US).<ref name=FraterSnowdeliv/> Adam Withnall of ''[[The Belfast Telegraph]]'' said that the budget was $645 U.S. dollars or about £420 British pounds.<ref name=Withnallamateur>Withnall, Adam. "[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/film-tv/news/verax-amateur-filmmakers-make-first-edward-snowden-movie-29457880.html Verax: Amateur film-makers make first Edward Snowden movie]." ''[[The Belfast Telegraph]]''. 30 July 2013. Retrieved on 3 August 2013. "But that is perhaps understandable on a budget of about $650 (£420), almost all of which was spent renting a room at the same hotel in Hong Kong where the US fugitive stayed."</ref> A one-night stay at The Mira was the most expensive single item in the budget,<ref name=FraterSnowdeliv/> and made up about one third of the budget. The filmmakers stated that they did not make the film to gain a return on their investment, and Jeff Floro,<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/> who works in finance as a day job,<ref name=IpStephanieProud>Ip, Stephanie. "[https://archive.is/20130804060925/http://www.calgaryherald.com/entertainment/movie-guide/Friends+proud+their+effort+amateur+5minute/8720729/story.html Friends proud of amateur film about Edward Snowden's Hong Kong stay]." ''[[Associated Press]]'' at ''[[Calgary Herald]]''. 29 July 2013. Retrieved on 3 August 2013.</ref> said that he lost money on the film.<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/>
Dean Napolitano of ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' wrote that "The film is not quite a "[[Saturday Night Live]]"-style spoof, but neither is it a slick thriller given its cast of non-actors and micro budget."<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/> Rebecca Keegan of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' stated that ''Verax'' "feels quite polished for an insta-film" due to the presence of electronic music soundtrack that she likens to [[The Social Network (soundtrack)|the soundtrack of]] ''[[The Social Network]]'', the "sweeping views of Hong Kong skyscrapers" and the shots within The Mira Hotel.<ref name=KeeganFilm/> Keegan added that "the actors' leaden delivery sometimes gives their neophyte status away."<ref name=KeeganFilm/> ''[[The Voice of Russia]]'' stated that the "shaky camera work" and the usage of local actors was "reminiscent of the [[Jason Bourne|Bourne]] spy thriller series."<ref name=VoiceofRussia/> Patrick Frater of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' said that the film had "strong production values, driving music and somewhat more amateurish acting performances."<ref name=FraterSnowdeliv/> Alexis Lai of ''[[CNN]]'' said that the film "is surprisingly suspenseful and sophisticated, with gorgeous time-lapse panoramas of the city and "shaky cam" shots reminiscent of Hollywood."<ref name=CNNLai/>
==Cast== The cast of the film consisted of friends of the four filmmakers. Dean Napolitano of ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' said that the cast had "varying degrees of thespian abilities".<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/> Andrew Cromeek, a 25-year-old American from [[Chester (village), New York|Chester, New York]] who was an English teacher, took the role as Snowden. He had previously acted in one commercial and one student film.<ref name=NapolitanoCromeekrole>Napolitano, Dean. "[https://blogs.wsj.com/scene/2013/07/02/becoming-edward-snowden/ Becoming Edward Snowden]." ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''. 2 July 2013. Retrieved on 2 July 2013.</ref> The filmmakers had reviewed any friends of theirs who they believed "remotely" appeared similar to Snowden.<ref name=AFPSnowdenfilm/> Shawn Tse said that he looked at all of his Caucasian (White) friends to see who could play Snowden.<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/> Cromeek worked at a company where Tse worked as a teacher.<ref name=DeMaraBoost/> Tse believed that Cromeek was "going to be perfect" for Snowden while Cromeek believed that he had "zero resemblance" to Snowden.<ref name=NapolitanoCromeekrole/>
According to Tse, he let Cromeek grow his beard out for several days before taking him to a Hong Kong barbershop.<ref name=DeMaraBoost/> Cromeek gave the hairstylist a photograph of Snowden and received a haircut for 50 [[Hong Kong dollars]] (US$6.41).<ref name=NapolitanoCromeekrole/> According to Tse the Hong Kong hairstylist warned Cromeek to be careful about being mistaken for Snowden.<ref name=CNNLai/> Cromeek then lightened his haircolor by using gold spray paint,<ref name=DeMaraBoost/><ref name=NapolitanoCromeekrole/> put on eyeglasses, trimmed his beard,<ref name=NapolitanoCromeekrole/> and on the day of the shooting had moles placed on his neck with makeup.<ref name=DeMaraBoost/><ref name=NapolitanoCromeekrole/> The film team also used a special wardrobe to make Cromeek appear like Snowden.<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/> Cromeek reported that his parents, family members, and friends gave him telephone calls after the film was made public.<ref name=NapolitanoCromeekrole/>
Cast list:<ref>{{YouTube|OWVGDBeR42I|"Verax"}}. (official YouTube page). Retrieved on 10 July 2013.</ref><!--Used to cite Chinese names--> * [[Edward Snowden]] – Andrew Cromeek * [[Central Intelligence Agency]] Station Chief Carl<!--Credits in the film say Thomas Hamilton but the updated video description says Carl Hamilton--> Hamilton – Thomas Easterling * CIA Analyst Owen Fielding – Gabe Ostley * CIA Operations Manager – Robert Hinson * [[Hong Kong Police Force]] (HKPF) [[Hong Kong Police Force#Security Wing|Security Wing]] officer Tsang Tak-long{{#tag:ref|{{zh|t=曾德龍|s=曾德龙|first=t,j|j=Zang1 Dak1 Lung4|p=Zēng Délóng}}|group=note}} – Edwin Chin{{#tag:ref|{{zh|t=錢尚文|s=钱尚文|first=t,j|j=Cin4 Soeng6 Man4|p=Qián Shàngwén|labels=no}}|group=note}} * HKPF Security Wing officer Vincent Lee{{#tag:ref|{{zh|t=李達志|s=李达志|first=t,j|j=Lei5 Daat6 Zi3|p=Lǐ Dázhì|labels=no}}|group=note}} – Justin Lau{{#tag:ref|{{zh|t=劉彥德|s=刘彦德|first=t,j|j=Lau4 Jin6 Dak1|p=Liú Yàndé|labels=no}}|group=note}} * HKPF Security Wing officer Vanessa Wu{{#tag:ref|{{zh|t=胡麗莎|s=胡丽莎|first=t,j|j=Wu4 Lai6 Saa1|p=Hú Lìshā|labels=no}}|group=note}} – Cindy Wong * [[China|Chinese]] [[Ministry of State Security (China)|Ministry of State Security]] Attaché Han Wei{{#tag:ref|{{zh|first=t|t=漢 衞|s=汉 衞|p=Hàn Wèi|labels=no}}|group=note}} – Simon Zeng Hao{{#tag:ref|{{zh|c=曾 昊|p=Zēng Hào|labels=no}}|group=note}} * Lecia Lau{{#tag:ref|{{zh|t=劉麗斯|s=刘丽斯|first=t,j|j=Lau4 Lai6 Si1|p=Liú Lìsī|labels=no}}|group=note}}, reporter at ''The South China Sentinel''<!--Fictional newspaper--> – Shi Yi Ng{{#tag:ref|{{zh|first=t|T=黃詩藝|s=黄诗艺|p=Huáng Shīyì|labels=no}}|group=note}}<!--If Ng is to Huang then Shi Yi Ng is of Teochew or Hokkien origins--> * Wu Xingwei{{#tag:ref|{{zh|c=胡星尉|p=Hú Xīngwèi|labels=no}}|group=note}}, editor of ''The South China Sentinel'' – Guo Aibing {{#tag:ref|{{zh|first=t|t=郭愛兵|s=郭爱兵|p=Guō Àibīng|labels=no}}|group=note}}
==Release and reception== The film was released on YouTube on Tuesday 25 June 2013.<ref name=AFPSnowdenfilm/> Several publications contacted the filming group for interviews, with ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' being the first and the ''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' (AFP) and the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' doing so afterwards. The interviews increased interest in the film.<ref name=DeMaraBoost/> By 28 June, it got over 5,000 views,<ref name=NapolitanoLCL/> and by 30 June it had gained over 8,500 views.<ref name=AFPSnowdenfilm/> By 2 July it got over 89,000 views.<ref name=DeHartDiplomat/> By 16 July it received over 220,000 hits.<ref name=DeMaraBoost/> By 30 July it received almost 250,000 views.<ref name=Withnallamateur/>
Luke Buckmaster of the online Australian political news magazine ''[[Crikey]]'' stated that ''Verax''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s "greatest asset is its showcase of narrative efficiency; of getting key points across using the language and arrangement of images to solicit logical (not necessarily emotional responses) and doing so without needing to put too fine a point on it."<ref>Buckmaster, Luke. "[http://blogs.crikey.com.au/cinetology/2013/07/09/all-about-efficiency-reviewing-verax-the-worlds-first-edward-snowden-film/ All about efficiency: reviewing Verax, the world’s first Edward Snowden film]." ([https://archive.is/20130721221544/http://blogs.crikey.com.au/cinetology/2013/07/09/all-about-efficiency-reviewing-verax-the-worlds-first-edward-snowden-film/ Archive]). ''[[Crikey]]''. Private Media Pty Ltd. 9 July 2013. Retrieved on 22 July 2013.</ref> Jin Jiabao of ''[[China Central Television]]'' said that the film's events were "vividly portrayed".<ref name=JinCCTV/>
Stephanie Ip of the ''[[Associated Press]]'' wrote that the film initially gained popularity but by 29 July 2013, "praise of the film has given way to criticism, with many viewers berating the four directors for amateur work and bad casting."<ref name=IpStephanieProud/> Adam Withnall wrote in ''[[The Belfast Telegraph]]'' that "many have criticised the four directors for amateur work and bad casting"<ref name=Withnallamateur/> and in ''[[The Independent]]'' that "a wider international audience hasn't been so forgiving of its less-than-professional quirks."<ref>Withnall, Adam. "[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/amateur-filmmakers-beat-hollywood-to-make-first-edward-snowden-thriller-movie-8736732.html Amateur film-makers beat Hollywood to make first Edward Snowden thriller movie]." ''[[The Independent]]''. Monday 29 July 2013. Retrieved on 13 August 2013.</ref> The cast of the television program ''[[New Day (TV program)|New Day]]'' said "We hope [Andrew Cromeek] and the rest of the cast are better at their real jobs."<ref>"[http://newday.blogs.cnn.com/2013/07/01/5-things-to-know-for-your-new-day-monday-july-1/ 5 Things to Know for Your New Day – Monday, July 1]." ''[[CNN]]''. 1 July 2013. Retrieved on 2 July 2013.</ref>
In regards to the criticism, Andrew Cromeek argued that the filmmakers did not expect to gain a large amount of attention on YouTube and that the filmmakers were not professional.<ref name=IpStephanieProud/> Cromeek said "I think the way it was shot was quite cool. We are all amateur actors. We all had one take. It was kind of like, shoot, go, OK, done. So it's fine. It's completely OK if people are like, 'It's the worst acting in the world.' It's totally fine with me."<ref name=Withnallamateur/> Ip wrote that ''Verax'' "is a source of pride for the friends who made it, even as they acknowledge its limitations."<ref name=IpStephanieProud/>

"[https://web.archive.org/web/20130707155320/http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/485884/20130703/edward-snowden-verax-short-film-amateur.htm#.Udwea6z6mSr SHORT FILM on NSA Leaker Edward Snowden, Verax, Created by Aussie Expat (Video)]." ''[[International Business Times]]''. 3 July 2013. *"[https://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2013/jul/05/edward-snowden-hong-kong-film-video-verax Edward Snowden's journey to Hong Kong dramatised in Chinese film – video]." ''[[The Guardian]]''. Friday 5 July 2013. *"[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GqZAaZDNtrg Hong Kong filmmakers first to make Snowden movie]." ([[Agence France Presse]] video report at YouTube) – [http://en-maktoob.news.yahoo.com/video/hong-kong-filmmakers-first-snowden-070644780.html alternate location] at ''[[Yahoo!]] [[Maktoob]]''.

"[http://www.mediaite.com/tv/watch-american-english-teacher-stars-in-hong-kongs-instant-edward-snowden-biopic-film/ WATCH: American English Teacher Stars In Hong Kong’s Instant Edward Snowden Biopic Film]." ''[[Mediaite]]''. 2 July 2013.

revision.comment: Incorrect; the first ever appearance of a Greek artist at Eurovision was Jimmy Makulis representing Austria in 1961.
revision.text:
{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Luxembourg}} "À force de prier" | image = [[Image:Nana Mouskouri - À force de prier.jpg|250px]] | caption = | year = 1963 | country = Luxembourg | artist = [[Nana Mouskouri]] | as = | with = | language = French | languages = | composer = Raymond Bernard | lyricist = Pierre Delanoë | conductor = Eric Robinson | place = 8th | points = 13 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1963lu from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = "Petit bonhomme" | prev_link = Petit bonhomme | next = "Dès que le printemps revient" | next_link = Dès que le printemps revient }} '''"À force de prier"''' ({{lang-en|"By Persistently Praying"}}) was the [[Luxembourg]]ish entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1963]], performed in [[French language|French]] by [[Greece|Greek]] singer [[Nana Mouskouri]]. This was the second appearance of a Greek artist on the Eurovision stage after [[Jimmy Makulis]] in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1961|1961]]. Greece as a nation would not join the Contest until [[Eurovision Song Contest 1974|1974]].
Mouskouri had had her international breakthrough with the [[German language]] single "Weiße Rosen aus Athen" ("White Roses from Athens") in 1961, a song originally adapted from a Greek folk melody. The song was later translated into several different languages and went on to become one of Mouskouri's signature tunes. When she received the offer to represent Luxembourg at the Eurovision Song Contest in early 1963 she and her family had recently relocated from [[Athens]], Greece to [[Paris]], France, where she was signed to the [[Philips Records|Philips]]-[[Fontana Records|Fontana]] label.
"À force de prier" is a ballad, with Mouskouri telling the object of her affections that she intends to have him love her "by persistently praying" for this to occur. Moskouri recorded her entry in French, German (as "Die Worte dieser Nacht"), [[English language|English]] ("The One That Got Away") and [[Italian language|Italian]] ("La notte non lo sa").
The song was performed sixteenth on the night, following [[Monaco]]'s [[Françoise Hardy]] with "[[L'amour s'en va]]". At the close of voting, it had received 13 points, placing 8th in a field of 16.
Although "À force de prier" was only a minor international success for Mouskouri, it won her the prestigious [[Grand Prix du Disque]] in France that same year, and her Eurovision appearance also caught the attention of noted French composer [[Michel Legrand]], who went on to write and arrange two major hits for her in the [[francophone]] markets; "Les parapluies de Cherbourg" (1964) and "L'enfant au tambour" (1965).
"À force de prier" was succeeded as [[Luxembourg in the Eurovision Song Contest|Luxembourgian representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1964|1964 Contest]] by [[Hugues Aufray]] with "[[Dès que le printemps revient]]".
